entry.title: Re: I can create delivery for a different shipping point...
entry.content: Why it happens is because, in SAP SD, the shipping point is determined at delivery creation time, not strictly fixed from the sales order. The system re‑runs shipping point determination based on your OVL2 configuration. Having said that, do you have multiple shipping points for the same combination in OVL2? To answer your question yes, it is standard SAP behavior. The delivery is technically independent and can be created with another valid shipping point if customizing permits. SAP does not hard‑lock the shipping point from the sales order to the delivery.

entry.title: Re: PO Creation ME21N
entry.content:
Each company code is assigned a country, and each country has a tax procedure (via OBYZ/OBBG). If MY02’s country is not assigned the same tax procedure (or no procedure at all), the system won’t propose a tax code.

In ME21N, the tax code can be proposed based on Condition records (via tax condition types in the pricing procedure), Account assignment category (e.g., direct cost center) and Plant settings (tax indicators in plant master). If LU27 has condition records or plant tax indicators maintained, but MY02 does not, you’ll see the difference.

If jurisdiction codes are active, the plant’s address (region, county, city) must be maintained. Missing address data in MY02 can prevent tax code determination.

For direct cost center postings, the cost center’s company code and controlling area must align. If MY02’s cost center master lacks tax‑related indicators, the tax code won’t default.

entry.title: Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily outlines the process of transferring legacy data of OTC transactions (money market, foreign exchange, OTC derivatives, and trade finance) from external systems into the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module, as a critical step in initial go-live data migration. The process is illustrated using an example of interest rate instrument (a product category of money market) in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is recommended:

  • The position components constitute the financial position of an interest rate instrument – refer to blog Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument or relevant SAP held documents for detailed context.
  • How accrual of interest income or expenses works – refer to blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure or relevant SAP held documents for detailed context.

It is also recommended reading the blog Legacy Data Transfer - Security Position, which may help you gain insights into the differences between OTC transactions’ legacy data transfer and security positions’ legacy data transfer.

Migration of Transactions

The financial transactions can be imported into TRM by using the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit. For migration of interest rate instrument, the migration cockpit object “TRM - Interest rate instrument” can be used. You can find more information regarding data migration of TRM from help document Treasury and Risk Management.

The specific steps for importing transactions via the Migration Cockpit are not elaborated on here. We assume the following investment transaction of interest rate instrument has been imported into the system, which means, the transaction has been created in TRM.

Major contract elements:

  • Nominal amount: 1,000.000.00 USD
  • Payment amount: 998,000.00 USD (discount: 2,000.00 USD)
  • Term start: 01.10.2025
  • Term end: 01.04.2026
  • Interest rate: 3% (act/360)
  • Interest frequency: 2 months
  • Repayment structure: financial repayment

Cash flow:

Enter Position Component Values

Let’s assume that the go-live of TRM is planned at 01.01.2026, so that the position component values of this transaction as of 31.12.2025 should be also migrated from position management and financial accounting perspectives.

Previously in the migrated/created transaction, we specified a general valuation class which derives the valuation class and position management procedure for Fair Value through OCI (FVOCI) within the valuation area 002 (IFRS). In this illustrative example, we will always focus on valuation area 002 only, the details for legacy data transfer of other valuation areas are omitted although they are also needed.

The underlying message is that, in the legacy system, this transaction is also classified and measured at FVOCI, and the position of this transaction as of 31.12.2025 may include the position components of purchase value, security valuation (including Security Valuation, Not Affecting P/L), FX valuation, in the terminology of SAP TRM. In the meantime, the accrual of interest income based on the nominal interest up to 31.12.2025 should also be considered. Moreover, since the company code’s local currency is EUR, the valuation currency is EUR, which is different from position currency USD (=the transaction currency), the values in both USD and EUR should be considered during legacy data transfer.

You may ask why choosing FVOCI to illustrate legacy data transfer, it is because FVOCI is more complicated than other classifications, such as amortized cost (no security valuation) or FVTPL (no amortization).

Now, let’s enter the valuation area-dependent position component values for this transaction by using the app Enter Position Component Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63C). Screen-shots:

Elaborate the data entered in TPM63C in below table:

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

Position Value Date

31.12.2025

 

Company Code

1010

 

General Valuation Class

22

 

Valuation Area

002

 

Transaction

1000000000107

 

Position Currency

USD

 

Valuation Currency

EUR

 

Security Valuation in Position Currency

500.50

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, these are the security valuation (mark-to-market valuation) in PC and VC which have been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Security Valuation in Valuation Currency

426.23

FX Valuation in Valuation Currency

-1799.10

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, this is the FX valuation in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Amortization in Position Currency

999.50

Positive value for positive amortization; Negative value for negative amortization.

In this example, these are the amortization in PC and VC which have been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the transaction in the legacy system.

Amortization in Valuation Currency

851.17

Security valuation, not affecting P/L, in position currency

500.50

Not needed if security valuation doesn’t update OCI (security valuation update P/L).

In this example, these are the Other Comprehensive Income (OCI) in PC and VC which have been recognized up to 31.12.2025 because of security valuation (which not affecting P/L) for the transaction in the legacy system.

Security valuation, not affecting P/L, in valuation currency

426.23

Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

2,583.33

Usually, positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from borrowing; negative value for accrual of expenses from borrowing, or deferral of income from investment.

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

2,195.31

Accrual/deferral with Reset

X

If this indicator is set, a reset business transaction for the transferred accruals/deferrals is generated additionally.

Reset Date

01.01.2026

If the reset date is not entered, the reset will occur on “position value date + 1”.

Notes:

  • Not every available field of TPM63C are listed in the above table.
  • Position component purchase value can’t be specified in TPM63C, because it has been determined by the operational cash flow within the transaction.
  • The amounts 2,583.33 USD / 2,195.31 EUR entered in the field “Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency” / “Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency” are the accrual account balances which represent the accrual for 31 days (01.12.2025 – 31.12.2025) out of the total 62-day calculation period (01.12.2025 – 01.02.2026) for the nominal interest flow due for payment on 01.02.2026.
  • In this example, the “Accrual/deferral with Reset” indicator is set, because the accrual of interest income for the nominal interest flows (update type MM1200+) after go-live will use Reset procedure. If the Difference Procedure for accrual will be used, then legacy data transfer for accrual part should be handled differently, there will be a separate section below to introduce it accordingly.

Beside manually entering the values via app TPM63C, there is a migration cockpit object “TRM - Position values” for mass importing the position component values.

Mark Flow as Fixed

After the transaction is changed to ‘contract settlement’ status, use app Mark Flows as Fixed - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TBB1_LC) to set the cash flows (up to 31.12.2025) to “Fixed” status without actually posting them.

The posting log is also available after successful execution of TBB1_LC, however, the document numbers are empty, because TBB1_LC doesn’t update general ledger accounting actually.

Check the cash flows in the transaction, the flows of principal increase (01.10.2025) and 1st nominal interest (01.12.2025) are “Fixed (not relevant for posting)”.

If you check the corresponding position flows through app Treasury Position Flows – Classic (app ID: TPM13), you will find they are also “fixed” in all valuation areas (screen-shot is omitted for TPM13 here).

It is highly recommended that you enter the exchange rates as of 01.10.2025 in the system (it is USD/EUR = 0.8516 in this this example), or edit the local currency amount of the cash flow with flow type 1100 in the transaction, before executing TBB1_LC. Because TBB1_LC will fix the valuation currency amount of MM1100- position flow, and update the position component of purchase value in valuation currency for position management. The MM1100- flow’s valuation currency amount (local currency amount in transaction’s cash flow) should reflect the corresponding exchange rate which was used to translate the transaction currency amount 998,000.00 USD to amount in EUR in the legacy system, otherwise the book value may not be correct in valuation currency amount after legacy data transfer.

You can also check the app Treasury Position Values - Classic (app ID: TPM12) for key date 31.12.2025. In TPM12, you can see the components Purchase Value in PC and Purchase Value in VC have been ‘determined’, and the deriving position component (e.g. acquisition value, amortized acquisition value, book value) are calculated accordingly.

Initial Load of Position Values

Use the app Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63) to read legacy data you’ve entered in TPM63C and transfer it to the position management of TRM.

There are 3 options for “Accounting Update”:

  • Do Not Update: choose this option if the accounting data is migrated via other means other than TRM (e.g. migrated the balances of position account, accrual account, OCI account in general ledger accounting). No posting will be generated from TPM63 if this option is selected.
  • Update: choose this option and then TPM63 will generate accounting documents for legacy data transfer related business transactions, usually using update type DT_*; and the postings rely on the account determination setup for those update types.
  • Update Only for Reset Business Transactions: if you have migrated accounting data by other means only up to the transfer key date, and you would like to post the reset business transactions (for amortizations, valuations, or accruals/deferrals) through TPM63, you can choose this option.

In this example, we choose Update to illustrate the whole picture of postings.

Log for TPM63 run:

You can also check the posting log by clicking Logs and Messages, the screen-shot is omitted here. Instead, let’s use the T-accounts to illustrate the effects of postings generated from TPM63 run:

First, look at the posting journals except the reset posting on 01.01.2026:

The position account, accrual account, and OCI account, all of the relevant balance sheet accounts have correctly reflected the balances which are equal to the legacy system’s data for this transaction, in both of position currency and valuation currency. The Financial Statement of Position as of reporting date 31.12.2025 then can be properly prepared in SAP system.

Please note the figures highlighted in orange are for the purchase value component. As previously mentioned, TPM63 doesn’t handle this position component, and TBB1_LC doesn’t make postings. To ensure the purchase value is presented in the position account balance as of 31.12.2025, there are at least two ways:

  • Post it directly in general ledger accounting; and the purchase value can be processed together with that of other transactions.
  • Use TBB1/TPM10 to post the business transaction of MM1100-, for which you may need to change its posting spec in advance. If this method is used, then TBB1_LC shouldn’t be used to fix MM1100-.

Check the position flows in TPM13:

Check the position component values in TPM12 as of 31.12.2025:

Illustrate the calculation logic of position component values in the following manner:

Let’s then include the effects of DT_C013 posted on 01.01.2026:

At the date 01.01.2026, the balance of accrual account is zero, and interest income account is debited in posting period Jan. 2025 (entries are highlighted in green).

You may have a question: usually the migration for financial accounting data should be limited to balance sheet accounts, why reset business transaction DB_C013 posts to P&L account in this example? Let’s move to the next section “Month-End Close after Go-live”.

Month-End Close after Go-live

During the first month-end close for Jan. 2026 after go-live, run TPM1 valuation for this transaction, before that, the NPV (fair value, 998,900.00 USD) has been entered for 31.01.2026. Check valuation log (The specific logic is not elaborated on here):

Run TPM44 accrual for key date 31.01.2026. Check log:

It is worth noting that TPM44 picks up the MM1200+ nominal interest flow with calculation-from date 01.12.2025 and calculation-to date 01.02.2026, totally 62 days within its interest period, and the AD1000 business transaction covers 62 days as well and accrues the whole period of MM1200+. You may raise a concern that shouldn’t TPM44 only cover 31 days (01.01.2026 to 31.01.2026), as the cut-off date for migration is the end of 2025? Under reset procedure, TPM44 always calculates the accrual amount starting from the calculation-from date of MM1200+, disregarding that its calculation-from is prior to the cut-off date. That’s why DT_C013 should debit interest income at the beginning of 2025.

Let’s check the T-accounts and position components in the following manner.

With the joint effects of DT_C013 and AD1000 in period of January, the interest income recognized because of accrual (and reset of accrual) in Jan. 2026 = 5,166.67 - 2,583.33 = 2,583.34 USD, this is the amount of interest income in position currency arising from the nominal interest that is attributable to Jan. 2025 from accrual accounting perspective. This kind of posting logic ensures the correctness of Income Statement as of Jan. 2026.

If the difference procedure is used for accrual, the approach to legacy data transfer should differ—for details, refer to the next section.

Difference Procedure for Accrual

Besides modifying the configuration to the style of difference procedure in the configuration activity 102925 “Assign Update Types for Accrual/Deferral” which has been descried in blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure, additional configuration should be added in the configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, sample configuration as below:

The indicator “direction” indicates whether the update type functions as an accrual/deferral (+ Inflow) or as a reset (- Outflow) of accrual/deferral.

With this setting, TPM44 run after go-live will be able to consider the accrual recorded via legacy data transfer (e.g., DT_C011) and include it in the accrual calculation as an offset of MM1200+, under difference procedure.

When entering position component values via TPM63C, the following values can be used. For fields not included in the table below, the corresponding values are consistent with those in the reset procedure example provided above.

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

…

…

 

Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

7,666.66

2,583.33 USD (accrual account balance as of 31.12.2025)+ 5,083.33 USD from the fixed nominal interest flow on 01.12.2025

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

6,503.43

2,195.31 EUR (accrual account balance as of 31.12.2025)+ 4,308.12 EUR from the fixed nominal interest flow on 01.12.2025

Accrual/deferral (2) in position currency

-5,083.33

Position currency amount of the fixed nominal interest flow on 01.12.2025

Accrual/deferral (2) in valuation currency

-4,308.12

Valuation currency amount of the fixed nominal interest flow on 01.12.2025

Accrual/deferral with Reset

Blank

 

Reset Date

Blank

 

Screen-shot of TPM63C:

Executing TPM63. The log of it:

Show the results in T-accounts as of 31.12.2025:

DT_C011 captures the amounts entered in the field “Accrual/deferral (1) in…currency” of TPM63C, while DT_C028 captures the amounts from the field “Accrual/deferral (2) in…currency” of TPM63C. From a posting standpoint, DT_C028 offsets against DT_C011, resulting in an accrual account balance of 2,583.33 USD / 2,195.31 EUR. This balance represents the accrual for 31 days (01.12.2025 – 31.12.2025) out of the total 62-day calculation period (01.12.2025 – 01.02.2026) for the nominal interest flow due for payment on 01.02.2026.

Run TPM44 for key date 31.01.2026 after go-live, the log is as below:

Because of the configuration made in 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, TPM44 incorporates DT_C011 into the accrual calculation, treating it as if the cumulative accrual that had been recognized via TPM44 in SAP TRM since the transaction’s inception and through 31.12.2025, and eventually results in the AD1004 business transaction representing the January’s incremental accrual amount 2,583.34 USD / 2,201.52 EUR, in addition, the FX correction business transaction 6.21 EUR with update type AD1020 is generated. The blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure explains this calculation logic of difference method.

Illustrating the positions of balance sheet accounts and situations of profit and loss (P/L) accounts as of 31.01.2025 (incorporating results generated from TPM1 and TPM44).

Additional Notes

  • You may always find more comprehensive information from help document Legacy Data Transfer.
  • Which DT_* update types are invoked for TPM63 is specified in configuration activity 106944 “Assign Update Types for Legacy Data Transfer”. Sample configuration:
  • This blog only outlines certain means and posting patterns associated with legacy data transfer; such postings can vary based on specific business requirements and can be implemented with the various flexibilities offered by the SAP system. For example, for migration of the accrual data under difference procedure, there is another approach:
    • In configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, specific DT_C011 and DT_C027 as the inflows for MM1200+.
    • Set DT_C027 as not relevant to posting in configuration activity 102101“ Indicate Update Types as Relevant to Posting”.
    • In TPM63C, enter the following accrual relevant data:

    • Field

      Data used in this example

      …

      …

      Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

      2,583.33

      Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

      2,195.31

      Accrual/deferral (2) in position currency

      5,083.33

      Accrual/deferral (2) in valuation currency

      4,308.12

      Accrual/deferral with Reset

      Blank

      Reset Date

      Blank

    • When running TPM63, DT_C011 captures the amounts entered in the field “Accrual/deferral (1) in…currency” of TPM63C, while DT_C027 captures the amounts from the field “Accrual/deferral (2) in…currency” of TPM63C. From a posting standpoint, only DT_C001 gets posted, resulting in an accrual account balance of 2,583.33 USD / 2,195.31 EUR as of 31.12.2025.
    • When running TPM44 on 31.01.2026, TPM44 incorporates DT_C011 and DT_C027 into the accrual calculation.
  • App Mark Flows as Reversed - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TBB3) is used to reverse fixing done by TBB1_LC, just like TPM10 reverses TBB1.
  • App Reverse Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM64) is used to reverse results from TPM63.

entry.title: Re: Exchange Rate Difference Postings at Payment Time – A...
entry.content:
Hi Chris, thank you very much for your detailed explanation.

I would like to clarify one point regarding my system setup, as I think this is where the misunderstanding may be. In my S/4HANA Public Cloud system, I only have:

• Company code currency: EUR

• Transaction currency: USD

I do not have group currency or any additional parallel currencies maintained. From a functional perspective, I therefore do not require any additional currency views beyond EUR (local currency) and USD (transaction currency). For this reason, I believe the issue I am seeing is not related to parallel currency balancing. To make the scenario clearer, below are the accounting entries generated by the system.

Goods Receipt:

Supplier Invoice:

Payment of the invoice:

What I observe is that, at payment time, the posting between the exchange rate loss account (group 6) and the exchange rate gain account (group 7) is created for exactly the same amount that was already posted as an exchange rate difference at invoice posting. This additional entry has no net impact on P&L in EUR and does not seem to be required for balancing purposes, given that only EUR and USD are involved. For this reason, I am still struggling to understand the functional purpose of this “mirror” posting between FX loss and FX gain accounts in my specific setup.

I hope this clarifies my question further, and I would really appreciate any additional insight or alternative explanation you might have regarding what could be triggering this behavior.

Kind regards,

Álvaro

entry.title: Cloud BAdI to Update Sales Document Business Data
entry.content:
Cloud BAdIs to Update Sales Document Business Data

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, following Cloud BAdIs can be used to modify some business data (standard fields) of sales document:

  • Modification of Business Data in Sales Document Headers - SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_BUSINESS 
  • Modification of Business Data in Sales Document Items - SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_BUSINESS

If you are familiar with the sales document data model, you will see these Cloud BAdIs mainly cover the sales document business data which are defined in the database table VBKD. 

Since the modification of business data BAdIs are kind of transactional BAdI, which are triggered multiple times during the sales document processing, the fields modification result could be checked at runtime if you are using UI to process sales documents. 

Of cause not all business data fields defined in the database table VBKD are modifiable via BAdI. The changeable fields in these BAdIs are normally independent from other business processes. 

BAdI Parameters

There are following typical parameters in BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_BUSINESS:

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data (including custom fields) that customer can use to write custom logic
SALESDOCUMENTPARTNERSSales document header partnersImportingContains sales document header partner information
SALESDOCUMENT_BUSINESSDATASales document business dataChangingContains all changeable fields on sales document header level

There are following typical parameters in BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_BUSINESS:

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data (including custom fields) that customer can use to write custom logic
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data (including custom fields) that customer can use to write custom logic
SALESDOCUMENTPARTNERSSales document header partnersImportingContains sales document header partner information
SALESDOCUMENTITEMPARTNERS
Sales document item partnersImportingContains sales document item partner information
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_BUSINESSDATASales document item business dataChangingContains all changeable fields on sales document item level

In the latest SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud version CE2602, following fields on sales document header level are modifiable in the BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_BUSINESS:

  • Pricing Date
  • Customer Purchase Order 
  • Customer Purchase Order Date
  • Incoterms Version
  • Incoterms
  • Incoterms Location 1
  • Incoterms Location 2

Following fields on sales document item level are modifiable in the BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_ITEM_BUSINESS:

  • Pricing Date
  • Customer Purchase Order 
  • Customer Purchase Order Date
  • Incoterms Version
  • Incoterms
  • Incoterms Location 1
  • Incoterms Location 2

Business Example

Due to fluctuation of raw material, the Supply company XYZ has special agreement with buyers to set the pricing date of sales orders based on different criteria. According to the business process of company XYZ, for different sales office, the pricing date offset is defined to make sure the pricing date is calculated with realistic time period. For example, when sales orders created from certain sales office, the pricing date is calculated 7 days after the requested delivery date. But there are exceptional case for some defined customer groups, the pricing date shall be calculated differently. 

Solution via Extensibility and Process Flexibility

Business Rules to Proposal Pricing Date

According to the standard feature "Flexible Proposal of Pricing Dates" (see detail in SAP_HELP), customer can define business rules to control calculation of pricing date. 

Therefore, I can define a business rule like below to influence pricing date calculation.

The "Baseline Date" in the CPF decision table defines the reference date of pricing date calculation. Below are possible options of baseline date:

  • null: Today
  • A: Requested delivery date (sales document header)
  • B: Valid-from date (sales document header)
  • C: Contract start date (sales document header/item)
  • 😧Document creation date

In SSCUI 104275, this CPF formula is assigned to routine 3000003 for flexible pricing date proposal

Then open the SSCUI 103823 to assign the routine 3000003 to sales order type "OR"

Once this CPF formula is enabled in sales order, we can test the pricing date proposal of sales orders. 

Create a new sales order via VA01, both requested delivery date and pricing date are defaulted as current date (26.12.2025)

Go to sales order header to change the sales office to "100".

Once the sales office is changed to "100", the pricing date is updated immediately based on CPF business rule: 3 days after current date. 

If I change the sales office to 101 again, the pricing date is updated accordingly to 7 days after.

🙀Hold on......

This blog is for Cloud BAdI, but here only the CPF is used. Do I miss any thing? 🤔

If you also have similar concern, please continue with below chapter. 

How Cloud BAdI Works

As I explained earlier, the pricing date is a changeable field in modify business data BAdI. The modify business data BAdI can also be used to modify pricing date on top of CPF proposed value. 

In the CPF decision table, the sales office is defined as key differentiator to control pricing date calculation. If the CPF criteria is not sufficient to fulfill the business requirement to determine the pricing date, BAdI can be used with more specific custom logic. For example, in the BAdI logic, I can make certain customers as exceptional case to propose pricing date. 

Open the tile "Custom Logic" to create a BAdI implementation for Cloud BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD_BUSINESS.

Implement the custom logic as below to always use "requested delivery date" as "pricing date" based on certain customer group.

*   This method can be used to set values to sales document header business data fields.
*   Example:
*
*   First, copy the values from the business data fields to the output parameter using a move-corresponding statement.
*   If you use developer extensibility and multiple implementations, embed the move-corresponding statement in an if statement.
*
    if salesdocument_businessdata is initial.
      move-corresponding salesdocument to salesdocument_businessdata.
    endif.

*   Update the pricing date
    if salesdocument-salesorganization = '1010' and salesdocument-salesdocumenttype = 'TA'.
        if salesdocument-customergroup = '02'.      "special customer
            salesdocument_businessdata-pricingdate = salesdocument-requesteddeliverydate.
        endif.
    endif.

Publish the BAdI implementation. 

Now, let's test the sales order creation with customer 10100001 who has the customer group "01" maintained, and another sales order with customer 10100004 who has the customer group "02" maintained. 

Create a sales order via Fiori v2 application.

The pricing date is determined by business rules in CPF decision table. Because the customer group for customer 10100001 is "01", the BAdI logic is not processed to set the pricing date. 

Create another sales order with customer 10100004, that the customer group "02" is defined. 

Even the sales office "100" is determined from customer master data, but because the customer group is "02" which fits to the custom logic in BAdI implementation, the pricing date is determined same as requested delivery date. 

In conclusion, the BAdI logic will overrule the pricing date which is proposed by CPF business rules. 

Moving Forward

The sales document business data BAdIs are well defined to influence sales document standard fields during document processing. Please always check if those BAdIs can fulfill your business requirements before introducing custom fields or checking other workarounds. 

We will continue investing on sales document business data modification BAdIs to enable more changeable standard fields. On the other hand, we also expect customers can raise requirement if any field is missing in those BAdIs. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal, see detail in SAP note 2963059. Stay tuned for new features planned in our roadmap.

entry.title: Flexible Integration in PP/DS with SAP S/4HANA SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
This blog describes the configuration and use cases for Flexible Integration using the ‘Scope Limitation’ in  SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for Planning & Scheduling in PP/DS with SAP S/4HANA.

It also introduces a new transaction /SAPAPO/SCOPE_SET, available as of SAP S/4HANA FPS0, which supports customers in performing mass changes of 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope  Profile' in material master data.

Flexible Integration provides customers flexibility to choose among different scope options for planning and scheduling between SAP S/4HANA-PP, -PP/DS, and external Line-of-Business applications like IBP.

This guide focus on Flexible Integration in embedded PP/DS and Production Planning in the core of SAP S/4HANA.

The capabilities of Flexible Integration are currently supported only for Integrated Business Planning (IBP) 2211 and above Real-time Integration and currently not supported with DSC Edition.

Note: This guide describes the settings that are only specific to the tested scenarios. Depending on your business processes, additional configuration settings and master data may be required.
For current constraints and restrictions, see the latest SAP Notes in SAP Service

Relevant SAP Notes
The following SAP Notes contain the most recent information and corrections to Flexible Integration
Ensure that you have the up-to-date version of each SAP Note, which you can find at: http://support.sap.com/notes.

SAP Note    Number Title
3073311    Restrictions & Implementation Recommendations for Flexible Integration in PP/DS on SAP S/4HANA
3634125    Restrictions and Implementation Recommendations for Prod. Planning and Detailed Scheduling in SAP S/4HANA 2025
3630469   Functionality to change scope settings in material master (mass processing)

Use Cases and Configuration of Flexible Integration

Flexible Integration in SAP S/4HANA IBP (Integrated Business Planning), Manufacturing Planning PP/DS (Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling) and SAP S/4HANA-ERP-PP supports various use cases through the introduction of Scope Limitations and Scope Profiles.

The primary Use Cases is the IBP Order-Based Planning Integration. Combinations of Scope Limitations support different IBP scenarios where materials are planned by IBP with results integrated into SAP S/4HANA MRP and PP/DS.

The production planning integration mode (PPIM)  in SAP IBP using Order-based Planning determines how a location product is handled in the integration of SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) order-based planning with Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling (PP/DS) in SAP S/4HANA.

For details refer to  SAP help: “Production Planning Integration Modes” and SAP Note “2640432 - Details on Restrictions for SAP IBP Order-Based Planning”

See relevant values of Scope Limitation to the IBP production planning integration mode (PPIM)

PPIM 2 and PPIM 4     -> Scope Limitation = ‘blank’ (PP/DS Entire Scope;
PPIM 5                            -> Scope Limitation = not applicable

In addition to IBP order-based planning, the flexible integration supports planning in SAP S/4HANA and  interactive planning and scheduling  PP/DS for SAP S/4HANA

  • MRP-Based Detailed Scheduling
  • DD MRP Integration (Demand Driven MRP)
  • Local Networks Planning

Customizing and Configuration 

Setup and Integration of Material and Product Master  Data

For the selected product locations, the behavior of Advanced Planning applications is determined by the Scope Limitation and Scope Profile configured in the Material Master > Advanced Planning tab.
In the SAP S/4HANA Core (ERP) system, maintain the Scope Limitation in the material master using transaction MM01/MM02.

In the Fiori app “Manage Product Master” you  can activate Advanced Planning in the Material master only for Materials without MRP areas and it is not possible to change the “Scope Limitation” of a Material with the Fiori app “Manage Product Master” because the function to Set Planning Lifecycle to ‘Marked for deactivation’ and to Execute the “Where-Used Check” is not supported in the app and only possible with the SAP Gui transaction MM02.

Maintain “Scope Limitation” and “Scope profile”  in the  material master data

  1. Open the material master (transaction MM02) in the SAP S/4HANA  system.
  2. On the Advanced Planning view mark the  Indicator for Advanced Planning Checkbox.
  3. Depending on your Flexible Integration Scenario enter on the Advanced Planning view  the following values:
  • Scope Limitation
    • 1 – PP/DS Display Only
    • 2 – PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only
    • 3 – PP/DS Restricted
    • 4 – PP/DS Entire Scope for Inhouse Only
    • ‘ ’ (Blank – PP/DS Entire Scope)
  • Scope Profile (when the ‘Scope Limitation’ of product is ‘2- PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only’ or ‘3 - PP/DS Restricted’=
    • SAP_PPDS01 (or customer Profile starting with ‘Y…’ or  ‘Z…’)

Picture: Scope Limitation and Scope Profile configured in the Material Master > Advanced Planning tab.

‘Scope Profile’ is only relevant when the ‘Scope Limitation’ is selected as ‘PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only’ or ‘PP/DS Restricted’. 

Depending on the which the 'Scope Limitation' is selected in the Material master the behavior of orders in PP/DS will be handled as follows: 

Note: For products with Scope limitation and Order CUD is allowed there is no Automatic “Multi Level Planning”  supported  (Planning Procedure = 3  to ‘Cover Dependent Requirements Immediately’ is not supported)

The options are as follow for Scope Limitation

  • 1 PP/DS Display Only
  • 2 PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only
  • 3 PP/DS Restricted
  • 4 PP/DS Entire Scope for Inhouse Only
  • ' ' (Blank) - PP/DS Entire Scope

Scope Limitations “1 PP/DS Display Only”

‘PP/DS Display Only’ Inhouse (e.g. Planned- and Production orders) and External Procurement Orders are transferred to PP/DS and will be Display only.

For Display Only Orders

  • Resources will not be loaded
  • Scheduling will be stopped
  • For External Procurement Orders, GR Processing Activity will be created with the GR Processing Time from the document
  • For Stock Transfer Orders & Requisitions: the Transport Activity will be added as the duration at the source and requirement time at the destination → Planned Delivery Time

There is no Create/Update/Delete (CUD) operations allowed on orders in PP/DS, thus no planning by PP/DS planning functions via Product View (/SAPAPO/RRP3) or PP/DS Product- or Service Heuristics possible.

For details which transaction support order details refer to SAP help “1 PP/DS Display Only”

See following a ‘Display Only’ order in PP/DS:


Picture: ‘Display Only’ Planned order in PP/DS
 

Scope Limitations “2 PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only”

With ‘PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only’ Inhouse (e.g. Planned- and Production orders) and External Procurement Orders are transferred to PP/DS.

External Procurement Orders will behave as ‘Display Only’ Orders  -  No Create/Update/Delete (CUD) operations and Planning Functions execution for the External Procurement Orders for Product Locations for which the 'Scope Limitation' is selected as PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only. 

Create/Update/Delete (CUD) operations allowed   in PP/DS for Inhouse orders but “restricted” to heuristics maintained in the 'Scope Profile' for Inhouse planning. Planner can only view external procurement orders in defined transaction like Product View (/SAPAPO/RRP3).

For details which transaction support the evaluate  of external procured order details refer to SAP help “2 PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only”

 

Scope Limitations “3 PP/DS Restricted”

With ‘PP/DS Restricted’ Inhouse (e.g. Planned- and Production orders) and External Procurement Orders are transferred to PP/DS and Create/Update/Delete (CUD) operations allowed on Inhouse- &  External orders in PP/DS.

Heuristic execution only of allowed for listed  heuristics in the 'Scope Profile'

For details which transaction support Inhouse- and  external procured order details refer to SAP help “3 PP/DS Restricted”
 

Scope Limitations “4 Entire Scope for Inhouse Only”

Inhouse- and External Procurement Orders are transferred to PP/DS.

Create/Update/Delete (CUD) operations allowed  in PP/DS for Inhouse orders but not for External Procurement Orders for Materials which have the 'Scope Limitation:  PP/DS Entire Scope for Inhouse Only’.

Planers can change Inhouse Orders but only view External Procurement Orders

For details which transaction are supports refer to SAP help “4 PP/DS Entire Scope for Inhouse Only”

Scope Limitations “’ ‘(Blank) – PP/DS Entire Scope”

The blank scope is selected by default in the material master.

There are no restrictions for Inhouse- and External Procured orders in PP/DS and all the PP/DS applications run without any restrictions.

 


Picture: PP/DS Transaction support on Scope Limitation

  Scope Limitations and Scope Profile in Materials with MRP Areas

For material master maintained for both Plant and MRP Area, the 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile'  on MRP Area will be defaulted  with the 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile' which are maintained at the Plant level. 

Scope Limitation at MRP Area can only  be edited when the Scope Limitation at Plant is PP/DS Restricted.

With PP/DS Restricted at Plant level the Scope Limitation at MRP Area can be PP/DS Restricted or Blank – PP/DS Entire Scope. 

For details refer to SAP Help Defaulting Plant Parameters to MRP Area

 
Picture: Scope Limitation on Plant and MRP Area level.

Business Application Programming Interface (BAPI)

The following Business Application Programming Interface (BAPI)s have been enhanced to respect the 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile' during the material master creation:

During material creation, user will be allowed to pass 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile' values to the BAPIs. These values will be validated and then saved to the table /SAPAPO/MATPLSTA. This logic is only applicable for OP (On Premise) and not for Cloud systems.

  • BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA
    Create/Change/Delete one  material at a time
  • BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEREPLICA
    Create/Change/Delete one or multiple materials at a time

With BAPI “BAPI_MATERIAL_GETALL” user can  read all the material data. This has been enhanced to read the MATPLSTA data as well. This logic is also applicable only for OP (On Premise) and not for Cloud systems.

For details refer to SAP Help Business Application Programming Interface (BAPI)

Settings in Scope Profile

When a Material has as ‘Scope Limitation’ ‘PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only’ or ‘PP/DS Restricted’ maintained in the Material master then the heuristics maintained under the ‘Scope Profile’ are allowed for heuristics execution in PP/DS.

SAP_PPDS01 is the default ‘Scope Profile’.

There are no changes allowed to the SAP Standard Scope Profile SAP_PPDS01.   You can maintain a new Scope Profiles with the namespaces (Z* or Y*) only.
See SAP Note ‘3094959 - Flexible Integration : OP2021 FPS1 : Material Master, Article Master & Scope Profile Changes’

 To create/maintain new Scope Profiles use the IMG node path: Advanced Planning --> Detailed Scheduling --> Maintain Scope Profile.

The SAP standard delivered ‘Scope Profile’ SAP_PPDS01 with 54 Heuristics.

Note: There are no Procurement Planning Heuristics for Production Planning in the Scope Profile.
As mentioned the primary Use Cases of Flexible Integration is the planning of a material in IBP or SAP S/4HANA-Core with results integrated into PP/DS for interactive order change/update/delete or Service- and Detailed Scheduling Heuristics.

 

Material Requirements Planning (MRP)

In SAP S/4HANA-Core you can use still use both: MRP Live (transaction MD01N) or Classic MRP (Transaction MD01) to calculates material requirements and creates procurement proposals.

The Transaction MD01 Classic MRP triggers only the MRP for materials not relevant to embedded PP/DS (advanced planning).

MRP for Materials relevant to advanced planning is triggered by the Production Planning Run in embedded PP/DS. (Transaction /SAPAPO/CDPSB0)

Picture: Material Requirement Planning (MRP) with seperate planning runs in SAP S/4HANA
("Classic-MRP MD01" in the ERP of SAP S/4HANA  and Production Planning Run in PP/DS)

This scenario is not according to SAP recommendation to run production planning in SAP S/4HANA with MRP Live  but still available and supported.

There are  Customers that are not moved from classic MRP  (transaction MD01)  to MRP live (transaction MD01N)  yet and run embedded PP/DS with SAP S/4HANA .

With this Scenario you have the restriction to coordinate & synchronize the MRP planning runs with Classic-MRP in the core of SAP S/4HANA and Production Planning Run in PP/DS

In this scenario , if a component is planned in the PP/DS system, then you must plan all components up to the BoM header material in the PP/DS system.

 


If you plan a component in the SAP S/4HANA-Core (ERP)  system, then you must plan all its sub-components in the ERP system.With Transaction MD01N MRP Live you trigger the  MRP for SAP S/4HANA Materials and Advanced Planning (PP/DS) Materials in ONE transaction.

 

Picture: With MRP Live ONE MRP in SAP S/4HANA

MRP Live dispatches SAP S/4HANA materials to be planned with either in the SAP S/4HANA-Core (MRP Live on HANA DB or Classic MRP)  or PP/DS Product Heuristics based on the Scope Limitation selected for the material.

   
Picture: MRP with Flexible Integration

Note: Multi-level MRP with synchronous integration
If a Material with LLC 0  (low level code, e.g. Finished Goods) have Scope Limitation  PP/DS Entire Scope (Example 4 for Inhouse or ‘Blank’) higher than material with LLC 1 (Example 1 or 2 or 3), it is not guaranteed that PP/DS would have created demand before MRP starts planning.
 

Changing Scope Limitation Values in Material master

To change the value of the Scope Limitation in the material master depends on the Planning Lifecycle of the Material and the extent to which a material is used in the SAP S/4HANA system, including the and scope and where-used in  master- and transaction data.

Change Scope Limitations values manual

To change the value in the material master manually for each material could be very time consuming.

Users have to enter the Material master  in change mode, check dependencies,  set values,  save the changes and Re-Enter a the material  several times. (up to 4-5 times)

For details refer to SAP help Changing Scope Limitation Values  

Procedure:        Maintain the Scope Limitation in the material master using transaction MM02.
Scenario:             Change Scope Limitation for a Inhouse produced component (Semi-Finished Good: TAA_SCOPE_SFG_101)  used as component in the BoM of a Finished Good (TAA_SCOPE_FG_10)

Step 1 Set Planning Status:

  1. Open the  Material Master > Advanced Planning tab. (transaction MM02).
  2. Set Planning Status (PLSTAT) to ‘Marked for Deactivation’
  3. Save

 

Step 2  Clear  (used-)data:

  1. Re-enter the Material Master in change mode.
  2. Execute ‘Where-Used’ list
     
  3. Run Where-Used Check to find references for the material  using transaction WUF
    1. On Where-Used List select Object Type  Adv. Planning Location Product
    2. Enter as Selection Criteria Product Number & Location
    3. Function “Execute”
  4. Check the result of the Where-Used Analysis and delete the data of the used object
    1. Delete the Production Data Structure (PDS) for component and the material that use the component in their BoM using transaction /SAPAPO/CULL_RTO_DEL

      Picture: Delete PDS for material and PDS that are using the  material as component

    2. Delete the Transaction Data / Orders using transaction /SAPAPO/CCR

      Picture: Delete Order data in PP/DS via Deltareport

    3.  further  data  may be  needed to be deleted…e.g.  orders that use the components

Step 3  Remove the Advanced Planning flag

  1. Re-enter the Material Master in change mode
  2. Execute ‘Where-Used’ list (No values Found)
  3. Remove the Advanced Planning flag for the material.

    Picture: Deactivate Adv.Planning Parameter

  4. Save the changes.


Step 4  Select new Scope Limitation value

  1. Re-enter the Material Master in change mode again.
  2. Re-set the Advanced Planning flag for the material and  select the Scope Limitation value from the drop-down list.

    Picture: Set Adv.Plan Flag

Step 5  Retransfer Master and Transaction data that use the updated material master

Note: The actual effort needed to bring a material into a state that scope settings can be changed is not accepted from customers – The interactive, manual maintenance effort is not practical in daily business

 

Change Scope Limitations values - mass processing

The 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile' cannot be changed using the Mass Maintenance transactions such as MASSD & MM17. 

With SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 , a new transaction /SAPAPO/SCOPE_SET, (based on the report /SAPAPO/PPDS_SCOPE_SET) is available, which  supports mass changes of Scope Limitation and Scope Profile, as well as the retransfer of orders from SAP S/4HANA Core to PP/DS if a scope change results in a change to the order content or structure.

With SAP S/4HANA  2025 FPS0 customers can select mass of materials or single material according to their needs and can change the scope settings automatically.

In case an order retransfer from SAP S/4HANA-Core PP to PP/DS is needed, a local deletion of orders in PP/DS as well as a re-transfer from SAP S/4HANA to PP/DS will be triggered automatically.


Picture: Screen of the new report for mass maintenance 'Scope Limitation'


Change 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile' using the Mass Maintenance

You can change the ‘Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile'  for a single or a mass of material master with the following procedure:

  1. Start ‘Change Scope Limitation & Scope Profile setting using transaction /SAPAPO/SCOPE_SET in the SAP S/4HANA system.
  2. In the Material selection area select one or multiple materials and define the target value for ‘Scope Limitation’ – For Scope Limitation  “2 - PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only” & “” also define the ‘Scope Profile’ (e.g. SAP_PPDS01)
  3. Define Scope Change on MRP Area for  Material with MRP Area
    See SAP help: Defaulting Plant Parameters to MRP Area
  4. For a first test you can run the report in test mode (Checkbox “Use test mode only”)
    This will not trigger any material master nor order change in the system, but if active you get a protocol
  5. You can save/log the protocol also in the test mode
  6. By “Active full logging” you get all details about scope changes with info about old and new values.
  7. Execute transaction


Picture: blocks in the log

 There are three main blocks in the Planning log / protocol

  1. Product Selection
  2. Organizing Products
  3. Processing Products

Product Selection:
You see the materials in which locations have been selected in the report.
There is no restriction if the target values “Scope  Limitation” and/or “Scope Profile” are already maintained  in the material or not.

Organizing Products
Number of selected materials within  a product  blocks based on the block size

Processing Products
See details of processing the materials in each block.
Among others see if materials cannot be locked
 (see Processing State “ENQUEUE_PRODUCST”), because they are locked by parallel sessions, thus they get filtered out from processing.
Also materials that have already the  target values from selection screen, get filtered out
(see Processing State “CHECK_PRECONDITIONS”). 


Picture: Log Details on order data transfer

Restrictions

MRP AreasScope Limitation and Scope Profile cannot be maintained at MRP Area level. The Scope Limitation and Scope Profile  maintained at the plant level will be defaulted at MRP Area
(See section ‘Scope Limitations and Scope Profile in Materials with MRP Areas’) 

Continuous Input/Output
Continuous Input/Output scenario will not be supported for Product Locations with Scope Limitation ‘1 - PP/DS Display  Only’ 

Fashion Article Master
Flexible Integration is not supported for Fashion Article Master and the fields Scope Limitation & Scope Profile will not be available in the Article Master screens (MM41/42/43).  

Mass change transactions (MASSD, MM17)
Only selection of materials based on ‘Scope Limitation’ & ‘Scope Profile’ is possible but not changing the values of ‘Scope Limitation’ & ‘Scope Profile’
(See section ‘Change Scope Limitations values - mass processing’) 

Production Planning Optimizer Recommendation
For the Production Planning Optimizer, recommendation is to use Product Locations with Scope Limitation ‘ ’ (Blank; i.e.  PP/DS Entire Scope)

Multi-level MRP with synchronous integration
If a Material with LLC0 (low level code) have Scope Limitation (Example 4 or Blank) higher than material with LLC1  (Example 1 or 2 or 3), it is not guaranteed that PPDS would have created dependent  demand before MRP starts planning   for material with LLC1
(See section 2.5 Material Requirements Planning (MRP)

Procurement Type Change
With 'Flexible Integration', creation of external procurement orders will not be allowed for Product Locations with 'Scope Limitation' as PP/DS Restricted for Inhouse Only and PP/DS Entire Scope for Inhouse Only during automatic heuristic execution. To ensure this, the procurement type for Product Locations will be changed from 'X' (Both procurement types) to 'E' (In-house at both Plant and MRP Area).
 

UseCase Demo Scope Limitation

In the following demo scenario, a company manufacture products for the business unit Aerospace (e.g. Engineer-to-Order) and business unit Automotive (e.g. Make-to-Order) in the same plant.

The materials for business unit Aerospace are planned in SAP S/4HANA-Core cause in thies demo this unit has not moved to from classic MRP (MD01) to MRP Live (MD01N) in SAP S/4HANA or there are other business reasons not to run Manufacturing for Planning & Scheduling in PP/DS. (e.g. Business unit runs an enhanced Proof of Concept to evaluate Aerospace planning requirements e.g. Parameter Effectivity)

The business unit of Automotive runs the production Planning/MRP already with MRP Live in SAP S/4HANA.

The production area ‘Standard Components’ (e.g. MTS)  runs also Manufacturing for Planning & Scheduling for semi-finished goods produce components that are used in the End-to-End BoM of Aerospace and Automotive. 

Picture: Scenario  with Use Case “Local Network Planning” and “MRP-Based DS”

Display Only
Finished Good ‘TAA_SCOPE_FG_10’ of business unit Aerospace has Scope Limitation “Display Only” –

  1. Orders of this  finished good are planned as use case ‘Local Network Planning’
    – Planning in the MRP of SAP S/4HANA-Core and ‘Display only’ in PP/DS cause  the production orders include  components  (TAA_SCOPE_SFG_101) that are produced on the same WorkCenter/Resource   (WC 2) than Automotive Semi-Finished Goods (e.g. TAA_SCOPE_SFG_201) – for  Detailed Scheduling  this orders need the  demand  quantity and  date & time.
  2. Creates the primary demand in the E2E BoM of the common product TAA_SCOPE_SFG_301, which is used in Aerospace as well as in Automotive part


Picture: “Display Only” orders with requirements (date & quantity)  but no activities and no Source-of-Supply (PDS)

 

PP/DS Restricted
Semi-Finished Good ‘TAA_SCOPE_SFG_101’ of business unit Aerospace has Scope Limitation “PP/DS Restricted”

  1. Orders of this semi-finished good are planned   as use case ‘MRP-based DS’ – replenishment elements planned SAP S/4HANA-Core-MRP and  Detailed Scheduling  in PP/DS cause they created capacity demand on the same resources (Res.2 – Machine)  than the  orders from Automotive Semi-Finished Goods (TAA_SCOPE_SFG_201)
  2. Orders of this semi-finished good are  planned  SAP S/4HANA-Core-MRP  and the orders create dependent demand / reservations on the Standard Component level – (“…SFG__301”) 

Picture: “PP/DS Restricted” orders with requirements (date & quantity) and activities
CUD  on orders possible but no product heuristic allowed 

PP/DS Entire Scope
There are no restriction on Manufacturing Planning & Scheduling for  Finished and Semi-Finished Goods of business unit Automotive (“TAA_SCOPE_FG_20, …SFG_201) and Semi-Finished Goods of the production area “Standard Components” –

These materials are planned with PP/DS Entire Scope


Picture: SAP PP/DS ‘Standard order’ – with all data required for Planning & Scheduling

  When business unit Aerospace implements also the overall scope of   SAP S/4HANA Manufacturing for planning and scheduling (PP/DS) and is going to run the MRP in PP/DS , the unit  can uses the mass maintenance ‘Change 'Scope Limitation' and 'Scope Profile' using  transaction /SAPAPO/SCOPE_SET (Report /SAPAPO/PPDS_SCOPE_SET)

Details see section “Change Scope Limitations values - mass processing”

I hope you enjoyed this blog and gained an overview about Flexible Integration  with SAP S/4HANA , how materials with flexible Integration are planned in SAP S/4HANA and got a high level overview of an use case with Planning in SAP S/4HANA Core and PP/DS with 'Local Planning Network,  'MRP-based DS' and Planning in PP/DS

entry.content:
Selam, Bakım Paketi sekmesi de dolu mu? 

Birde mapping de ilgili stratejinin hangi devresi ile ilgili eşleşmede olmalı.

entry.title: Execute SAP PaPM UM API via SAC through Multi Actions’ API step
entry.content:
Introduction

User can trigger SAP PaPM Universal Model API via SAC Multi Actions’ API Step, here is the step by step blog to set up such a workflow.

Create Multi Action with API Step to trigger SAP PaPM UM API

  1. Create HTTP API Connection
    1. Choose Connections on SAC menu
    2. Choose Add Connections
    3. Search “HTTP API”
    4. Fill in the required connection information, then choose Create.

  1. Create Multi Action and add API step connecting to the public API of SAP PaPM UM

  1. Execute Multi Action
    1. This multi action can be executed in story, analytics application, and scheduled via Calendar. Here is the example of running in Story.
    2. Add Multi Action Starter.
    3. Choose this Multi Action on the builder panel.
    4. Execute this Multi Action.

  1. Check calculation result on SAP PaPM UM
    1. The PaPM UM process is generated.
    2. Choose “Show Data” to check the calculation result on TOTAL column.
    3. The result of TOTAL is correct.
      • The value of “QUANTITY” we set in Multi Actions’ API Step is “2”, according to the calculation rule “TOTAL = AMOUNT*QUANTITY”, the formula is “AMOUNT*2”, so the result on TOTAL is correct.

Summary

With Multi Actions API step, user can execute SAP PaPM UM API via SAC. What's more, Multi Actions can be parameterized which largely reduces maintenance effort for admin users.  Business users execute multi action with defined context and scope by assigning parameter values flexibly. 

You can find more details in the blog of Multi Actions API Step. Integrate remote application via API step of Multi Actions

entry.title: Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
entry.content:
Picture 1: SAP BDC – Cash Flow Dashboard

 MOTIVATION

 In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

 The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

 Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

 

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting (THIS BLOG POST)
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

 

INTRODUCTION

 Just a few years ago, only 4 in 10 employees relied heavily on data in their daily work. Fast forward to today, and that number is expected to surpass 70%. That’s nearly double in less than a decade.

At the same time, we’re seeing an explosion in data volumes, driven not just by traditional sources, but by the rise of GenAI, which is generating massive amounts of synthetic data. By 2030, we’re looking at up to 10x growth in data volumes.

And all of this comes at a cost. Quite literally. The average cost of managing data has more than doubled over the past decade.

So while data is becoming a strategic asset, it’s also becoming a growing burden. The question isn’t just how to manage it, but how to turn it into a true competitive advantage without being overwhelmed by its complexity and cost.

If data are organized and harnessed as a product, then it can significantly reduce costs of data management and improve data discoverability and reusability. Specifically, a McKinsey study in a 2022 Harward Business Review suggests Data Products will reduce time for new case implementation for up to 90% and decrease TCO by up to 30%.

In this context data organized as Data Products also offer benefits to the planning and forecasting business processes.

 

WHAT IS A DATA PRODUCT?

Data products, just like traditional products, are standardized data assets designed to deliver measurable value to its users. They encompass all the essential components needed for their utilization: not just data, but also metadata, including governance policies, data quality rules, data contracts, and, where applicable, a software bill of materials to document their dependencies and components. Adhering to the FAIR principles – findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable – a data product is designed to be discoverable, scalable, reusable, and aligned with both business and regulatory standards, driving innovation and efficiency in modern data ecosystems.

Picture 2: Data Products are searchable, discoverable and easy to consume logical packages of data

Data Products are also a central component SAP Business Data Cloud. With their delta sharing capability based on open-source Linux Foundation protocol they improve access to third party data and make SAP data more accessible to third party solutions. SAP data products and other key BDC components are described in detail by my colleague @Nektarios_Vasileiou33 in this blog Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC

SAP DATA PRODUCTS

SAP-managed vs customer-managed Data Products:

  • Starting with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP is providing a comprehensive set of SAP-managed data products across the Lines of Business (LoB). Customer only need to activate these predefined data products and then SAP takes care for extraction, loading and data curation. Here is an updated list and description of the currently available SAP Managed Data  Products on our Business Accelerator Hub.
  • Customer also can create their own customer-managed data products to enhance the set of data products with data from any SAP or non-SAP application. Customer-managed data products are curated in SAP Datasphere. The data and ORD file(s) are stored in the customer-managed object store within SAP Datasphere.
  • Both type of data products are technically identical. They are stored in an object store, described via ORD file and published in the SAP BDC data catalogue.

 

Picture 3: SAP Managed Data Products in Datasphere Catalog

 

LEVERAGING DATA PRODUCTS IN PLANNING

Data products are valuable for corporate planning because they turn raw data into reusable, discoverable, and trustworthy assets that planners can access directly instead of waiting for bespoke extracts or ad-hoc reports. Easier access removes bottlenecks: planners spend less time requesting data and more time analyzing scenarios, which speeds decision cycles and improves responsiveness. A well-designed data product provides a single source of truth and consistent definitions (e.g., standardized customer, product, or revenue metrics), reducing confusion and disagreement across teams. When data is exposed through APIs, semantic layers, or curated data marts, non-technical users and analytical tools can query it reliably without bespoke engineering work. Built-in metadata, lineage, and documentation increase trust and make it easier to validate results for budgeting, forecasting, and risk assessments.

Data products also enable automation of recurring planning tasks—like rolling forecasts or variance analysis—so companies can run more frequent, higher-fidelity planning cycles with less manual effort. They support scenario modelling because productized datasets are versioned and auditable, letting planners compare alternative assumptions with clear provenance. By centralizing and governing access through SLAs, access controls, and data contracts, organizations reduce duplication of effort, lower data preparation costs, and decrease the chance of using stale or incorrect inputs in strategic decisions. Cross-functional collaboration improves because different stakeholders work from the same curated datasets, speeding alignment and reducing reconciliation work during planning meetings.

 

Picture 4: Leveraging Data products enables easier data access for planning

In the context of SAP Data products for planning these can be:

  • SAP managed: for most SAP based cloud applications (S/4HANA PCE and LoB solutions like SuccessFactors or Ariba) or
  • Custom managed: customer defined for on-premise applications, partner based (i.e. PWC, McKinsey, etc.), 3rd party (i.e. weather, benchmark data, etc.) that could be coming from Data marketplace in Datasphere   

 

STEP-BY-STEP EXECUTION BASED ON EXAMPLE

Net Working Capital Planning (based on NWC core data products)

We wish to perform Net Working Capital (NWC) planning based on actual and short term forecast data from S/4HANA. With the help of SAP delivered data products, we will significantly reduce the effort needed for data search, preparation and modelling. As a first step, we will search in BDC for the Cash Flow data product which is deployed and periodically loaded with fresh master and fact data from S/4HANA.

 

Picture 5: Out-of-the-box Cash Flow Data Product contains the actuals needed for our planning use case

 

The Cash Flow and several other data products like Journal Entry, Company code, etc. form the view and analytic model for New Working Capital in BDC. This large data set we will in the first step filter and limit the dataset to the dimensions that we need for planning. We keep it simple and decide to plan our NWC on Company Code and Profit Center so we use the Data Boulder in Datasphere to create a limited view. We also filter the facts to a specific year and currency.

 

Picture 6: Data Builder in Datasphere to help us limit the Data Product content to what we need for planning

 

Once our view is deployed, we can switch to SAP Analytics Cloud to build our planning data model. We navigate to Modeler and choose to create a new model, start with data and select we want to use a model from Datasphere where we just used several data products to design our NWC planning view. We select our view, and SAC will use its data structure to design the planning model for us.

Picture 7: Instead of building the planning model from zero, we use the Data Product view to auto-create the model

 

We get a model which includes the live version of NWC facts and the dimensions we defined in the Datasphere view.

Picture 8: Auto-generated planning model based on a data product view

 

We now must define semantics for our model columns and add master data wherever required. While the latter step currently requires some manual work, this will be dramatically reduced in 2026. SAP plans to deliver within the Seamless Planning Roadmap the possibility to re-use master data in SAC from Datasphere without the need of replication.  In addition to master data creation, we also expand the time dimension to allow for the planning time horizon and configure the currency unit for the measure. Finally, we expose our planning model to Datasphere so we can apply the seamless planning approach and potentially make use of further data products if needed for our planning use case.

Picture 9: Finished SAP Analytics Cloud model ready for planning

 

Based on the created model, we can create a story and start planning our net working capital for 2026. Since our model includes a live version of actuals residing in my data product, we can start our planning based on actuals from 2025. Live Versions (stored externally to our planning model) can in Seamless planning be applied throughout the planning workflow—stories, data actions, predictions, calculations, and more. This feature introduced in Q4 2025 is in detail explained by @MaxGander in an excellent recent blog post.

 

Picture 10: Planning layout for net working capital planning based on data products

 

Extending NWC planning with HR data (based on SuccessFactors data products)

We decide we wish to include other data to refine our NWC planning and make it more comprehensive. We can perform another search in the data catalog of BDC and add other relevant data products. While NWC is primarily driven by the operating cycle (receivables, inventory, payables) in some businesses employee headcount and related compensation costs can have a significant indirect impact.

We perform a search in BDC data catalog and amongst multiple SAP-managed data products for SuccessFactors find the one relevant one for employee compensation data.

Picture 11: SAP-delivered Compensation data product

 

Similarly to the example with NWC data we would create a view on the Actual Compensation data product to focus and filter relevant data for planning.

Picture 12: Use of Data Builder in BDC to limit the Data Product content to what we need for planning

 

We can now add a new measure in our planning model on SAP Analytics Cloud to store compensation data and make use of External Live Versions to connect the Compensation View we created before.

Picture 13: Connecting another External Data Source from BDC in our model

 

We need to map the dimensions of our new compensation data source with the dimensions in our planning model.

Picture 14: Mapping of dimensions for the Live Compensation data

 

In final step we adjust our story that we already used before for NWC planning and copy the actual compensation data into a planning version. Now we can start flexibly using the new compensation driver to model a calculated measure or a data action that will allow us to simulate how plan compensation influences our NWC based on some logic that we define. Note that our case and data are simplified as we are focusing on BDC capabilities and not on business logic in this blog.

Picture 15: Story in SAP Analytics Cloud combining data from both views built on BDC data products  

 

OTHER USE CASES

In addition to the use cases that we described in the above example, data products are also easily sharable due to the delta sharing capability. This allows for easy sharing of actual and plan data to third party tools that could be used to enrich our data. One such example is the potential to use SAP Databricks to apply ML on our plan data. We could use the ML results to automate parts of the planning process (i.e. apply an advanced time series forecasting algorithm in Jupiter Notebooks to actual data to generate a forecast). One of these examples will be described in detail in the blog Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks which is also part of this blog series to be published soon.  

 

SUMMARY

In summary, there is considerable value in data products for planning, and it is measurable:

  • time-to-insight decreases
  • the number of one-off data requests drops
  • declined operational costs tied to manual data wrangling
  • imporved forecast accuracy and plan-to-actual variance

To capture these benefits, companies should identify high-impact planning needs, expose datasets via discoverable interfaces (data products), and monitor usage and quality over time.

 

USEFUL LINKS

In case you are interested to implement the concept od data products and Data Fabric please refer to this article for implementation tips SAP What is article on Data Products.

Our architecture center includes some interesting architectural information on this topic Data Products in BDC.

In SAP Learning you can learn more on exploring and installing SAP Managed data products Learning.

Finally also our Help content describing the Data Sharing Cockpit in Datasphere is a valuable resource explaining how to create and manage the your data product’s lifecycle.

entry.title: Re: BRF+ Billing Output management (On-premise - Sold to...
entry.content:
Two options you have which are

Instead of relying only on condition parameters, you can build a BRF+ decision table that reads the sold‑to party from the document context (via the BAdI) and applies your logic. This gives you full flexibility to say “If Sold‑to Party = X, then output type Y is relevant.”

You can add a new condition parameter to the OPD application by enhancing the BRF+ application. This involves creating a new field (e.g. Sold‑to Party) and linking it to the billing document context. SAP provides extensibility for OPD via BAdI depending on release. In the BAdI, you can populate the sold‑to party into the BRF+ context so it becomes available for condition evaluation.
