entry.title: Re: Hi All,The class CL_ABAP_TYPEDESCR is released API in...
entry.content:
@Erol_CAGLARUse the button </> to format the code.

DATA cds_name    TYPE sxco_cds_object_name.
DATA lt_elements TYPE if_rap_query_request=>tt_requested_elements.

cds_name = i_request->get_entity_id( ).

DATA(h1_handler) = xco_cp_cds=>view_entity( cds_name ).

IF h1_handler IS NOT INITIAL.

  DATA(ltc) = h1_handler->fields->all->get( ).

  LOOP AT ltc INTO DATA(lc).

    DATA(cnt) = lc->content( ).
    DATA(lv_pk) = cnt->get_key_indicator( ).

    IF lv_pk = 'X'.
      DATA(fld) = cnt->get_original_name( ).
      lt_elements = VALUE #( BASE lt_elements
                             ( CONV #( fld ) ) ).
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.

  lv_req_elements = concat_lines_of( table = lt_elements
                                     sep   = `, ` ).
ENDIF.

entry.title: Turning Insight into Impact: Driving Adoption and Value through the Guided Buying Usage Report
entry.content:
Many organizations implement SAP Ariba Guided Buying (Guided Buying) with intent, but lack visibility into how employees actually use it — specifically, who logs in, what they search for, and where they encounter difficulties. This leads to silent inefficiencies: low adoption, inconsistent compliance, off-system purchases, and unrealized savings.

The Usage Report bridges this gap by helping transform user activity into actionable insights that enable organizations to drive adoption, enhance user experience, and convert digital buying into measurable business value.

The report tracks key behaviors — from logins and cart additions to searches and empty results — revealing adoption trends and usability gaps often hidden behind spend data.

Used strategically, the Usage Report becomes a roadmap for continuous improvement. Each metric tells a story: low logins show awareness gaps, empty searches expose catalog issues, and stagnant cart activity signals process friction. Translating these insights into actions—such as enriching catalogs, simplifying navigation, or reinforcing change management—boosts adoption, curbs maverick spending, and strengthens compliance. Over time, guided buying evolves from a transactional tool into an intelligence layer that connects people, processes, and technology for measurable procurement excellence.

The Seven Metrics That Reveal the Health of Your Guided Buying Adoption

Distinct Users Logged In – ‘The Pulse of Adoption.’
Every digital transformation starts with visibility into user participation. Adoption is a key success metric for business leaders.

Q- What is the business value of the ‘Distinct Users Logged In’ metric?

A – This metric indicates the number of employees who engage with guided buying, measuring adoption health, and ensuring it becomes the default starting point for all purchases.

The example below shows that 35,812 distinct users signed in to guided buying over one month.

Compare this number to the total number of employees authorized to make purchases in Guided Buying to evaluate the success of your automated self-service procurement initiative.

Q – What should be done if the ‘Distinct Users Logged In’ metric is low?

A –  Below are a few short measures that will help

  1. Analyze system performance metrics and response times to identify technical barriers that might be impacting user experience.
  2. Survey users on barriers to system usage - Gather direct feedback on obstacles preventing regular login.
  3. Validate user permissions and role assignments - Ensure proper access rights and persona-based configurations.
  4. Management must promote Guided Buying through campaigns and demonstrate its value.
  5. Review training completion rates and user onboarding - Assess knowledge gaps and support needs.
  6. Run a campaign to educate users on how Guided Buying can be a one-stop shop for all their purchasing needs, such as:
    1. Create, view, and approve requisitions
    2. approve, reconcile, and view invoices
    3. Create non-PO invoices
    4. Create, view, and approve receipts/SES

Q – What features and functionalities in Ariba Guided Buying can be used to improve the ‘Distinct Users Logged In’ metric?

A - Promote Guided Buying as a one-stop shop for all procurement needs in the organization. Enabling the following features in Guided Buying can help attract users to the platform.

  1. Custom Forms - Custom Forms in SAP Ariba Guided Buying offer flexibility for non-standard processes. Examples of Custom Form use cases include Asset Tracking Forms and Capital Purchase Authorizations.
  2. Tactical Sourcing - Enabling organizations to allow users to request quotes from suppliers through Guided Buying.
  3. Invoice Capabilities - Users can perform basic tasks with invoices without needing to navigate to other areas.
  4. Redirect users to guided buying instead of classic Ariba Buying
  5. Self-Service Transfer of Ownership - Any user can submit a transfer of ownership form for purchase requisitions or invoices.
  6. Supplier database: Manage qualified and preferred suppliers. Your vendor management team designates preferred suppliers for non-catalog requests by commodity code and region, guiding casual users. Suppliers are listed as qualified or preferred on guided buying requests based on the selected commodity and region.
  7. Joule Capabilities in Guided Buying: SAP's generative AI copilot, Joule, utilizes a conversational interface to help users complete tasks efficiently. It leverages generative and other AI technologies to understand natural language requests, identify intent, perform actions, and provide insights.

Q – What are the business risks of ignoring the ‘Distinct Users Logged In’ metric?

A – If users don’t log in to Guided Buying and bypass it, it will result in low adoption and poor ROI.

Q – How should organizations benchmark the ‘Distinct Users Logged In’ metric?

A – Each organization is at a different stage of its value journey; therefore, its targets will also vary. However, organizations should track the ‘% of eligible users who log in to Guided Buying monthly’ and aim to increase it as much as possible over time.

 

Distinct Users Added to Cart – ‘Moving from Awareness to Action.’
Logging in Guided Buying is one thing — taking action is another.  Number of individual users who have added products and services from the customer catalog to their shopping carts in a month

Q- What is the business value of “Distinct Users Added to Cart”?

A –This metric indicates whether users actively engage with the Guided Buying. A low number of distinct users adding items to cart indicates poor conversion from browsing to purchase intent in Guided Buying.

The example below illustrates that 27,691 distinct users added at least one item to their cart within a single month.

Compare this number to the total number of employees who are allowed to purchase in Guided Buying to measure the success of your effort to provide automated self-service procurement.

Q – What could be the potential causes for a low ‘Distinct Users Added to Cart’ metric?

A - Several factors could be affecting the user’s ability to transact, with some of the most prominent listed below. 

  1. Missing required permission to create requisition.
  2. Catalog content problem - Insufficient catalog items or missing product information
  3. Product discovery problem – Inefficient and poor search results
  4. User training or awareness gaps - Casual users and functional buyers are unfamiliar with the Guided Buying cart features and procurement workflow.
  5. Technical barriers - Session timeouts or technical errors preventing successful item additions.
  6. Process workflow or approval concerns - Users are hesitant to add items due to unclear approval processes or uncertainty about policy compliance.

Q – What features and functionalities in Guided Buying can be used to improve the “Distinct Users Added to Cart” metric?

A – Below are recommended features and functionalities that should help

  1. Product recommendations using AI - A more straightforward way to buy and stay compliant
  2. Implement persona-based dashboards and customized shopping experiences to enhance user engagement and satisfaction. The guided buying capability can be flexibly configured for each user, presenting them with personalized tiles and categories to streamline their purchasing experience.
  3. Enhance search capabilities - Enables an enhanced search experience for users.
  4. Users will benefit from easy-to-understand guidance, powered by WalkMe for Guided Buying, a digital adoption platform embedded in Guided Buying.

Q – What are the business risks of ignoring the “Distinct Users Added to Cart” metric?

A - Business impact includes reduced procurement efficiency, lower user adoption, and missed opportunities for compliant purchasing.

Q – How do organizations benchmark the “Distinct Users Added to Cart” metric?

A - Aim to keep this metric around the organizational baseline (typically, it should be 40-60% of active browsing users) and track this metric monthly to see how your interventions are producing results.

 

Distinct Items Added to Cart – A Window into Catalog Relevance

A diverse range of items in user carts indicates that guided buying truly serves business needs.

Q- What is the business value of the ‘Distinct Items Added to Cart’ metric?

A – The ‘Distinct Items Added to Cart’ metric reflects how well catalog content aligns with demand across various functions. A narrow or repetitive set of items suggests catalog gaps or limited choice — a cue for procurement to review coverage, enhance descriptions, and enrich metadata for discoverability.

This example illustrates that 19,441 distinct items were added to the cart by all users across all sessions during one month.

Compare this number to the "Distinct Users Logged in" number to see how many items were added to the cart per session.

Q – What could be the potential causes for a lower number of ‘Distinct Items Added to Cart’ metric?

A - Several factors could be affecting the user’s ability to add a broader range of items, with some of the most prominent listed below. 

  1. Navigation complexity: Users may struggle to locate the desired items.
  2. Search functionality performance: Poor search results may discourage users from adding items.
  3. Catalog accessibility issues: Items may not be visible due to the catalog views
  4. Product description quality: Incomplete or unclear item descriptions may prevent users from confidently adding items to the cart
  5. Integration connectivity: Issues with supplier punch-out connections may prevent item additions

Q – What features and functionalities in Ariba Guided Buying can be used to improve the ‘Distinct Items Added to Cart’ metric?

A - Features and functionalities such as Catalog Content Management, PunchOut Catalogs, Keyword Mapping, etc., can help.

  1. Consider spot buy capability for items not available in standard catalogs.
  2. Optimize catalog organization with better categorization and filtering options.
  3. Enable partial item functionality for products requiring additional specifications.
  4. Promote specific catalog items as preferred items.
  5. Review and streamline approval policies that may be creating barriers.
  6. Configure validation policies to provide clear guidance rather than blocking actions.

Q – What are the business risks of ignoring the “‘Distinct Items Added to Cart’ metric?

A - Limited choice leads to frustration, which leads to offline buying.

Q – How do organizations benchmark the ‘Distinct Items Added to Cart’ metric?

A - Track monthly growth in unique items added.

 

Searches (Top 20 with Results) – Understanding What Users Really Want
Behind every purchase lies a search. This metric shows the top 20 searches conducted by users that returned at least one result.

Q- What is the business value of the Searches (Top 20 with Results) metric?

A – This metric highlights what employees most frequently seek. It exposes actual buying patterns — often more accurately than spend data.

Analyzing the top 20 search terms helps procurement ensure that the most sought-after goods and services are well-cataloged, properly categorized, and always available.

The category manager should plan to add related items to the ones that are in demand.

The example below displays the top 20 search terms over a one-month period. Use this metric to see the relative popularity of search terms during the month.

It shows that users searched for shirt 614 times during the month, which was the fourth most popular search term during that month.

Note that an individual user may have searched for ‘shirt’ multiple times during the month, which could skew the results; the "Distinct Users Search" (below) provides more accurate numbers.

 

Distinct Users Search (Top 20 with Results) – Tracking Demand Across the Organization
It shows the Top 20 searches performed by individual users who performed searches that yielded results. When many users search for the same terms, it highlights collective demand and cross-departmental needs.

Q- What is the business value of the ‘Distinct Users Search (Top 20 with Results)’ metric?

A – The Distinct Users Search metric identifies where demand is concentrated, enabling more accurate forecasting and effective category planning. It also helps evaluate the effectiveness of taxonomy and search filters, ensuring users can find what they need quickly and intuitively.

This example displays the top 20 search terms used by distinct users within one month.

It shows that distinct users searched for ‘laptop dock’ 498 times during the month, which was the fourth most popular search term among distinct users during that month.

Q – What are the business risks of ignoring the Search metrics?

A - Poor catalog relevance leads to wasted time and low satisfaction. Poor search success rates impact user adoption and procurement efficiency.

Q – How do organizations benchmark the ‘Searches metric?

A - Benchmark top 20 searches vs catalog coverage.

 

Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results) – Exposing Catalog Gaps and Spend Leakage
This metric shows the Top 20 searches performed by users that yielded no results.  Empty search results are a silent drain on procurement efficiency.

Q- What is the business value of the ‘Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results)’ metric?

A – The Empty Search metric lists the most common search terms that return no results — clear indicators of catalog gaps or missing suppliers.

This example shows the top 20 search terms that produced no results within one month.

Q – What are the business risks of ignoring the ‘Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results)’ metric?

A - Each unfulfilled search is a potential maverick purchase waiting to happen.  Increased empty search results leading to potential maverick spending and increased help desk contacts.

Q – How do organizations benchmark the ‘Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results)’ metric?

A - Reduce empty searches by 30% or more per quarter by expanding the catalog coverage and reducing any other barriers to search items.

 

Distinct Users Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results) – Measuring the Scale of Frustration

This metric shows the Top 20 searches performed by individual users that yielded no results. It shows the scale of users impacted by failed searches.

Q- What is the business value of the ‘Distinct Users Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results)’ metric?

A – It’s one thing to know which terms return no results — it’s another to know how many people are affected. The ‘Distinct Users Empty Search’ metric measures the prevalence of these issues.

The example below shows the top 20 search terms by distinct users that produced no results within one month. It’s an example that shows there are only a handful of users for whom empty results were returned, indicating excellent work by the Category team.

Q – What are the business risks of ignoring the ‘Distinct Users Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results)’ metric?

A - Frustration will lead to disengagement and higher off-system spend. If multiple users repeatedly face failed searches, frustration builds, and trust in guided buying erodes.

Q – How do organizations benchmark the ‘Distinct Users Empty Search (Top 20 with No Results)’ metric?

A - Track the number of unique users affected over time. Monitoring this trend helps ensure a quick response to high-impact usability gaps. This section of the usage report helps the category team prioritize items for catalog expansion.

Q – What could be the potential causes for poor Search results in Guided Buying?

A - Several factors could be affecting the user’s search results, with some of the most prominent listed below. 

  1. Catalog content issues: Incomplete item descriptions, missing keywords, poor categorization, or insufficient product information.
  2. Search configuration problems: Suboptimal search parameters, missing equivalent words, or inadequate search algorithm tuning.
  3. User behavior patterns: Users searching with terms that don't match catalog terminology or searching for unavailable items.
  4. Restricting catalog views.
  5. System performance factors: Search indexing issues, relevance ranking problems, or catalog re-indexing delays.

Q – What features and functionalities in Guided Buying can be used to improve the Searches?

A - Features and functionalities listed below will help.

  1. Catalog content enrichment: Improve keywords in item descriptions and short names to match user search patterns.
  2. Search parameter tuning: Configure search boost parameters to prioritize relevant results.
  3. Spot Buy Marketplace makes it simple for employees to purchase non-sourced goods from trusted suppliers, adhering to built-in controls.
  4. Synonym management: Implement Equivalent words functionality to match user terminology with catalog terms.
  5. Training recommendations: Educate users on effective search techniques and available search functions.
  6. Deploying request forms and Line Item forms for missing items. Both form types serve as structured alternatives when catalog items are unavailable, providing users with procurement pathways instead of failed searches.

 

How to get started on the Adoption, Savings & Compliance journey?

The Usage Report is available only after you set the guided buying parameters PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH and PARAM_ENABLE_USAGE_REPORTS.

When you enable this feature, administrators will see a new ‘Usage Reports' section on the Admin page, which allows them to download a report on user searching and shopping behavior.  

Turning Data into Action — Building a Culture of Continuous Improvement
The real value of the Usage Report lies not in collecting data, but in taking action based on it. When procurement teams combine their insights with usage reports’ analytics, they create a continuous feedback loop that drives improvement. This cycle strengthens adoption, reduces off-system purchases, and aligns buying behavior with business goals.

From Data to Decisions: Leadership at the Core of Adoption

For leaders, guided buying success is measured not by system rollout but by adoption, compliance, and the realization of value. The Usage Report makes these outcomes visible and measurable, shifting the focus from usage to impact. By regularly reviewing insights, leaders can close adoption gaps, drive behavioral change, and embed data-driven decision-making across teams—transforming guided buying from a transactional tool into a strategic enabler of efficiency, savings, and agility.

entry.title: Re: RES1 smaller than accrual REA2 same value as RES1
entry.content:
What is happening technically is that REA2/YRA4 → This is the standard condition type for accruals (posting to accrual account). In your example, it correctly builds up 197,40 €. REA5/YEA5 → This is the accrual clearing condition type used during settlement. When you enter a manual payout (say 5 €), the system interprets it as:

  • Clear the accrual (197,40 €)
  • Post the payout (5 €)
  • Net effect: accrual reduced by 197,40 + 5 = 202,40 € → leaving 187,40 € in accrual, which looks like “double deduction.”

This is why you’re seeing the accrual reduced by more than expected.

Why it behaves this way is because, the REA5/YEA5 condition is designed for full clearing of accruals when you settle rebates. If you only want to pay out a partial amount, the system still tries to clear the accrual and then post the payout, so the math looks wrong. SAP standard assumes that settlement = clearing accruals + posting payout. It doesn’t natively support “partial payout, leave accrual balance untouched” without customizing.

Options to fix this is

Use partial settlement functionality
In rebate agreements, you can run a partial settlement (transaction VBO2 → Settlement → Partial). This posts only the payout amount (e.g. 5 €) and leaves the accrual balance intact. The condition types used must be configured for partial settlement (not REA5).

Custom Z condition logic
Many customers create a Z condition type for “payout only” that posts directly to the vendor/customer account without clearing accruals. This way, you can pay 5 € and leave the accrual untouched at 192,40 €.

Check your settlement procedure
In customizing (V/06, VBO1 agreement type), ensure that REA5/YEA5 is not applied in cases where only partial payout is intended. Instead, use REA3 (partial settlement) or a Z‑condition that mimics it.

entry.title: Re: Add Access Sequence to Condition Type NAVM
entry.content: NAVM has no access sequence by design and it is set to statistical in pricing procedure. Also routine 029 is assigned to this condition type in pricing schema which blocks automatic input tax determination. Adding an access sequence will make NAVM behave like a normal condition type, but you must remove routine 029 and maintain condition records. The main impact is on pricing procedure behavior, condition record maintenance, and FI postings. Safer option is to use NAVS or a Z condition type for automatic tax code determination, rather than altering NAVM.

entry.title: Re: Job to check STOs w/o outbound deliveries and create it
entry.content: Use VL10B / VL10G (Delivery Due List) scheduled as background jobs to automatically create outbound deliveries from STOs. These transactions already handle the “check if delivery exists, otherwise create” logic, so they fit your workaround perfectly.

entry.title: Re: How to create a PR with item hierarchy for lean servi...
entry.content: BAPI_PR_CREATE does not support item hierarchies. To create PRs with hierarchies programmatically, you must use Lean Service Management classes (CL_MM_PUR_SRV_HIERARCHY) or enrich via BAdIs. The HL_ITEM logic is only available in PO BAPI, not PR BAPI. So yes, it is possible programatically, but not with BAPI_PR_CREATE alone, you need to use the newer service hierarchy framework.

entry.title: AI: Augmented Intelligence... really?
entry.content:
After having explained in a previous blog post why AI was starting to worry me, particularly regarding youth employment, I'm sharing with you today an experiment I conducted for Christmas, and also a rant about the very poor use of AI by someone who is supposed to be a professional journalist…

An amusing experiment?

To amuse my family, I decided to portray myself as Santa Claus: thanks to my white beard and mustache, I do have a certain predisposition 🎅🏻 So I submitted my profile picture to Google's Gemini, with the following prompt: "This man dressed as Santa Claus, sitting near a Christmas tree with plenty of gifts around him and below the tree. A warm and festive atmosphere, with a bright light" And here's the result:
 
Pierre Col as Santa Claus, seated

 

To look a bit more dynamic and cheerful, I then submitted the following prompt: "Another image with Santa Claus standing close to the Christmas tree, not sitting, and with a good smile":
 
Pierre Col as Santa Claus, standing

 

And to amuse my former colleagues at SAP, I submitted the following prompt: "The same image, with Santa Claus dressed in blue and with an SAP logo on his coat":
Pierre Col as corporate SAP Santa Claus

Looking back, I find these images frighteningly realistic. Indeed, those who know me "for real" know that this isn't my real smile:

 
Pierre Col doesn't smile like that.
 
But for everyone who knows me, whether closely or from afar, this could be a real photo of me wearing a Santa Claus costume:
 
Pierre Col, portrait as Santa Claus.
 
So, from now one, which images can we really trust?
I'm now almost certain that in a year or two, no one will be able to distinguish a real "photo" from a fake one… 😮
 

When a journalist does AI slop

 
When I stumbled upon this post by Bruno Jeudy on X social network yesterday, I was overcome by a mixture of anger and sadness. The now-famous (in France) Intermarché wolf says "Noèl", really?!?
 
 
Indeed, Bruno Jeudy presents himself as "Political Journalist, Deputy Director of La Tribune Dimanche, editorialist at BFMTV and La Tribune, commentator on "C dans l'air"" and his LinkedIn profile confirms it.
 
 
So, let's assume he knows how to spell "Noël" (Christmas in French).
But the AI ​​he used to produce this image is clearly incapable of spelling "Noël" correctly.
❓️ Did Bruno Jeudy, inattentive as he was, not notice this glaring error?
❓️ Did he fail to correct it, either with a new prompt or with image editing software, and, driven by the desire to create a buzz, deliberately choose to share this grossly flawed image?
 
In either case, he gives the impression of someone who doesn't care at all about the quality of what he shares.
It's catastrophic.
Are we going to let what's now called "AI slop" invade our lives?
 
🙏🏻 To all of you reading this, please avoid doing the same at work; it will be better for everyone. 
 

That being said… Merry Christmas!

entry.title: Error during Universal Journal Release for Consolidation Unit in MXN with Standard Version P01 and G
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are facing an issue during the Universal Journal release task in SAP Group Reporting for period 2026.01. The scenario is as follows:

  • Consolidation Unit: Local currency MXN
  • Standard Planning Version: P01 (Budget in MXN)
  • Group Currency Extension Version: P11 (Budget in USD)
  • Integration: Universal Journal → Group Reporting

When executing the release, we receive the error:
FINCS_ACCTG_INTEG003 – The group currency of the version does not match the currency derived from the group currency source for all relevant companies.

What we observe:

  • In ACDOCP, the data looks like this (see screenshot):
    • Impte.MT, Impte.MS, Impte.MG, and ImpMonFunc all show MXN values for the consolidation unit.
  • In the Validation Plan report, version P11 (USD) also shows MXN amounts, even though we expect 0 USD until the currency conversion process runs.

Questions:

  1. Is it correct that ACDOCP stores the amounts in MXN for both versions (P01 and P11) before conversion?
  2. Could this error be caused by incorrect data sent from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Planning? Or is it purely a configuration issue in Group Reporting versions and currency source settings?
  3. Should the Universal Journal release validate the group currency before conversion, or allow the process to continue and then apply conversion?

Additional Details:

  • Both versions are set to Direct Update in the report.
  • Group currency for P11 is USD, but the source of group currency might be misaligned.
  • The expectation: P11 should either show 0 USD or converted values, not MXN.

Screenshots:

  • ACDOCP extract showing MXN values in all currency fields.

  •  

  • Validation Plan report showing MXN in P11 instead of USD.

  • GC of version P11 and GC source currency for CoCd of company MXSAFN differ.

    Diagnosis

    To execute a data release task successfully, the Group Currency of the version must match the currency derived from the version’s Group Currency Source for all relevant company codes.

    For example, if the Group Currency of the version is set to EUR and the Group Currency Source of the version is set to Freely Defined Currency 2, then the system checks to ensure that the Freely Defined Currency 2 set for all relevant company codes is also EUR. If this isn’t the case, then the data release task can’t be executed successfully. This is because the amounts would be transferred into a different group currency. For example, 100 EUR would be transferred as 100 USD.

    Procedure

    There are four different options to fix this: 

        1. In the
     Define Versions 
      Customizing activity, adjust the version’s group currency so that it matches the currency derived from the version’s group currency source for all relevant company codes.
        2. In the
     Define Versions 
      Customizing activity, adjust the version’s group currency source so that the derived currency of all relevant company codes matches the group currency of the version. Alternatively, you can remove the group currency source in the selected version since this is an optional setting. This results in transferring amounts in local currency only. In this case, no check regarding group currency is executed.
        3. In the
     Define Settings for Ledgers and Currency Types 
        Customizing activity, adjust the currency set for all relevant company codes, which is derived from the version’s group currency source so that it matches the group currency of the version. For example, if the version’s
     Group Currency 
        is
     EUR 
        and its
     Group Currency Source 
        is
     Freely Defined Currency 2
        , set the Freely Defined Currency 2 of all relevant company codes to
     EUR
      .
        4. Change the master data field
     Universal Journal Integration 
        from
     Transfer from Universal Journal 
        to
     No Integration 
      for the selected consolidation unit. As a result, there is no release task for you in the data monitor. Instead, you must then upload data to group reporting either via flexible file upload or via data transfer from SAP Group Reporting Data Collection.

     

    Message No. FINCS_ACCTG_INTEG003

Has anyone experienced this behavior? Is this a standard design (data stored in local currency until conversion), or does it indicate a configuration or integration issue?

Any insights or best practices would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: How to use the new Google IDE Antigravity with SAP (and CAP)
entry.content:
We hear that with the new SAP ABAP Cloud on Visual Studio Code, more and more developers will move to the “new” IDE.
We already know that Business Application Studio is a cousin of Visual Studio Code.
Do you know who another cousin is?

Spoiler
Google Antigravity!

In this brief blog post, I will present what it is, why you should use it, how to install all components, how to use it with SAP, and my final thoughts after an intensive weekend of use.

This guide focuses on Windows and Node.js installation (no Java). ⚠️
My personal impressions are from an Apple user perspective. 🤙

What is Google Antigravity?

Google Antigravity is a new IDE forked from Visual Studio Code.
I started using it based on a colleague’s suggestion, mainly because:

  • Advanced agent-based development model
  • Google as a strong and reliable engineering brand
  • Support for running multiple agents in parallel
  • Unique planning and “vibe coding” experience
  • Temporary free access to Gemini Pro and Opus models (only for this you should try it!)

Why not give it a try?

Download Antigravity

Google Antigravity Download

If you have never used Visual Studio Code before

The following steps help you get started if you are completely new to Visual Studio Code and Antigravity.

 

1. Install Node.js

Download the latest Node.js version and complete the installation:

Node.js — Download Node.js®

 

2. Install CDS Tools for CAP Development

Install the CAP development kit globally:

npm i -g @sap/cds-dk

Note: the -g parameter installs the tool globally and only needs to be executed once.

3. Install Cloud Foundry CLI

The CF CLI is required for Cloud Foundry operations such as application deployment and service management.

You can download it from the SAP Development Tools page (Cloud tab):

SAP Development Tools

 

Verify the installation:

cf -v

If Antigravity was already open during installation, restart it.

Install the Multi-Target Application plugin:

cf install-plugin multiapps

5. Install Chocolatey and MTA Build Tool (MBT)

Chocolatey is optional. I use it to install GNU Make, which is required by the MTA Build Tool during the build process.

Chocolatey installation guide:

Installing Chocolatey

Install the MTA Build Tool:

npm install -g mbt

Verify the installation:

mbt -v

Configure Plugins and Marketplace for SAP in Antigravity

Antigravity is based on an open-source ecosystem and does not have direct access to all official VS Code plugins. This requires a small configuration change.

From my perspective, the most important plugins are:

  • SAP Fiori Tools
  • CDS Tools
  • CAP Tools
  • SAPUI5 Extension
  • UI5 XML Support
  • Remote Access for SAP Business Application Studio

Go to File > Preferences > Antigravity Settings

 

Set the following values:

 

Marketplace Item URL:
https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items

Marketplace Gallery URL:
https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/_apis/public/gallery

Please restart Antigravity after this change ⚠️

Install all your favorite plugins:

 

Configure MCP Server

At this point, I recommend configuring the MCP server with the Antigravity AI chat. Here I only describe the CAP MCP configuration, but if you want more info, this is the original post with the most important MCP servers: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable age... - SAP Community.

In the agent view, select the three dots (…) and choose MCP Servers


, then Manage MCP Servers,


and finally View raw configuration.

Paste the following configuration:

{
  "servers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {},
      "type": "stdio"
    }
  },
  "inputs": []
}


Restart Antigravity to complete the setup. ⚠️

To learn more about MCP servers, refer to: MCP – A Comprehensive Guide

Final Conclusion after Intensive Use

Antigravity is still a young product. I had to restart it multiple times during my work, and I consumed the Gemini Pro and Opus credits fairly quickly.

Visual Studio Code still feels more stable, and SAP’s tooling is clearly more mature there. However, switching between the two is extremely easy, which makes experimentation low risk.

I did not fully experience the benefits of multi-model usage yet—this may be due to configuration or limited testing time. Still, I recommend exploring it and trying it out during your vibe coding sessions.

Let me know how your experience goes and what your impression is of this new IDE.
Pro or Cons?

entry.title: Re: How to update a source of an UNION in a graphical view
entry.content:
Hi Xavi, 

I simulated the issue and yes, graphical views behave this way. 

Initially there is the Line Currency field from the other source. But UNION requires to have all fields defined, this is mandatory when working with UNIONs in a SQL view (I work mostly with SQL views). Therefore I would say, that in case you add a new field, the graphical UNION expects that all sources and all source fields are 1:1 and mapped already (like in SQL view), therefore any new fields is automatically added and mapped.
In your case, the Line Currency should already exist in the fist source at least as a dummy ('DUM' AS "Line Currency"). I would say, that the graphical UNION should not allow creating fields from unmapped sources in the first place, but I guess this is wanted thus working as designed.

My suggestion would be to create dummy fields in the sources, same approach as SQL view.

 

Martin

entry.title: Hedonic Pricing: What Do Investors Pay For?
entry.content:
Executive summary
Investors do not primarily pay for short-term margin spikes or isolated growth initiatives.  Instead, over a 35-year horizon, the market has consistently rewarded one thing above all else: persistency.  This is the term Goldman Sachs attaches to the capital structure discipline, specifically leverage (Assets/Equity).  We find that leverage explains the majority of the variation in Home Depot’s Market Cap / Equity, our proxy for the Price/Book ratio.  This finding closely replicates Goldman Sachs’ famous analysis of what markets pay for, but applies to a single company and validates using long-horizon time-series data. Profitability and efficiency matter — but they come second.

This note describes our findings in three simple blocks:

  • data preparation and transformation
  • results and interpretation
  • what it means for Home Depot and investors.

 

1. Data preparation: looking at Home Depot the way markets do

This analysis starts from a simple premise:

If we want to understand how investors value Home Depot, we must model Home Depot the way investors observe it.

We assembled 144 quarters (1990–2025 YTD) of data covering both market valuation metrics (P/B ratio, Market Cap, Enterprise Value) and accounting fundamentals (assets, equity, leverage, margins, asset turnover).

This is important: unlike cross-sectional studies across many firms, this model is time-series for a single company. We are not asking why Home Depot is valued differently than Lowe’s.  We are asking a more precise question:

What has historically driven changes in Home Depot’s valuation over time?

Log transformations: elasticity, not levels

All core variables are expressed in logarithmic form. This is essential for interpretation:

  • Coefficients become elasticities
  • Relationships become scale-free
  • Long-term growth dynamics dominate short-term noise

In plain English: we are modeling percentage changes investors respond to, not absolute dollar movements.

The dependent (predicted) variable is the

ln(Market Cap / Equity), a proxy for the P/B ratio, directly links market valuation to balance-sheet fundamentals — exactly how long-term equity investors think.

Three independent (predictor) variables are

Leverage = (Assets - Goodwill) / Stockholders Equity where we specifically remove Goodwill to account for “tangible leverage” only,

Net Margin = Net Income / Revenue, 

Turnover = Revenue / (Assets - Goodwill) here too, assets are net of goodwill for "tangible turnover."

In one quarter, Home Depot reported negative net income. In 9 quarters the company reported negative equity - initially in 2019 as a result of the adoption of the FASB ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases (Topic 842)".  This is why the lines in the plot below exhibit discontinuities: natural logarithm of a negative number is undefined.

In log terms, valuation and operating fundamentals move in clear and persistent co-movement over time.  Sustained multiple expansion coincides with rising operating efficiency, greater leverage capacity, and improving margins, while periods of valuation compression align with broad-based fundamental deterioration.  Valuation itself behaves as a slow-moving state variable, reflecting investors’ long-run assessment of economic capacity, whereas operating metrics adjust at higher frequency around that state.  Even during externally imposed disruptions—such as recessions and market panics—temporary dislocations give way to re-convergence, underscoring that market multiples are ultimately disciplined by fundamentals rather than driven by sentiment alone.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This systematic co-movement directly motivates a hedonic valuation, in which observed market multiples are modeled as the equilibrium price investors assign to distinct operating characteristics rather than as standalone time-series outcomes.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

2. The hedonic pricing regression: what explains Home Depot's valuation?

Conceptually, the model mirrors the DuPont identity, which decomposes Return on Equity into three elements:

  • Leverage (Assets / Equity)
  • Profitability (Net Margin)
  • Efficiency (Asset Turnover)

Our model - with the log-transformed data - is:

To accommodate periods of negative net margin and negative stockholders’ equity, we introduced dummy variables that flag sign changes (0 for positive values, 1 for negative).  The inclusion of dummy variables allows the model to accommodate sign changes without materially altering coefficient magnitudes or inference. 

The regression, run in R Studio, produced a formula where most coefficients are statistically significant at the 5% level (p<0.05).  The ln_net_margin variable returned a p-value of 0.0744, indicating a 7.4% probability of observing this result (or one more extreme) if there were actually no relationship between ln_net_margin and ln_mktcap_over_equity.

We drop the decimals:

Here is the most intuitive interpretation of the model’s coefficients and log-terms: elasticity. These bars represent standardized coefficients, not raw elasticities, and are intended for relative magnitude and intuition, not literal percentage translation.


 

Home Depot’s valuation is most sensitive to changes in asset turnover, indicating that improvements in capital efficiency drive market multiples more powerfully than margin expansion alone.

In raw log terms, leverage can be interpreted as follows: a 1% increase in leverage increases Market Cap / Equity by approximately 1%.

Net margins exhibit a comparatively modest elasticity, suggesting that accounting profitability, while important, does not independently command valuation premiums.

Taken together, the results align closely with how long-term equity investors think: sustainable valuation expansion is rooted in efficient deployment of capital, not short-term margin optimization.

 

The key result: persistency dominates

The model has R2 of 94.05% and Adjusted R2 of 93.91%.  If we decompose the individual predictors’ contribution to this explained variance in Market Cap/Equity, the key conclusion emerges:

Visually, this is striking: the largest block by far is leverage. Most of what investors paid for Home Depot over 35 years is captured by three variables of which Leverage is the most significant. This is what Goldman Sachs found in their panel data analysis calling the hedonic pricing element persistency.

Persistency, in Goldman’s framework, means:

  • Stable capital structure
  • Predictable balance-sheet scaling
  • Consistency in how equity is multiplied into assets and cash flows

What we have done here is replicate that insight, but:

  • For one company
  • Using 35 years of quarterly data
  • With a fully transparent regression framework

The alignment is almost exact.

Notably, the model contains no explicit time trends, macroeconomic variables, or sentiment indicators—yet it explains over 94% of valuation variation, underscoring how consistently markets price the same economic fundamentals.

In Home Depot’s case, leverage alone explains roughly two-thirds of the market’s valuation signal. Profitability matters — but it is secondary, less persistent, and less trusted by investors as a long-term signal.

Both actual and predicted series represent the log market-cap-to-equity multiple where

The chart shows that a simple three-variable hedonic model tracks Home Depot’s valuation remarkably well over more than three decades. Even though the model has no awareness of time, cycles, or sentiment, its predicted valuation closely follows the actual market valuation across multiple regimes. Deviations between the two lines are concentrated in periods of market stress or speculative excess, while long-run trends are captured cleanly.

In other words, investors consistently price the same economic fundamentals, though they might temporarily lose discipline during panics and recessions.

This directly supports the executive intuition captured in the quote by Dilip Shanghvi, the founder and CEO of Sun Pharmaceuticals:

“I will never risk capital; but I will risk profit.”

Markets agree.

 

3. How solid is our model? Is it "too clean"?

No serious business model should avoid this question.

Residual behavior (what we checked)

We explicitly reviewed:

  • Residual distribution
  • Residuals vs. fitted values
  • Time clustering during stress periods

 

 


 


 

With F-statistics 684.4 on 3 and 130 degrees of freedom and p-value < 2.2 x 10-16, the model is structurally sound, though markets still panic occasionally — and then revert.

That is exactly what we would expect from real investors.

What do residuals tell us

Residuals widen during periods of macro-financial stress, including the Global Financial Crisis, COVID, and the post-2022 rate shock. This is expected: markets temporarily price fear, liquidity constraints, and narrative risk beyond firm-level fundamentals.

Outside stress regimes, residuals oscillate tightly around zero with no persistent bias. Deviations cluster in time rather than by sign, indicating regime effects rather than model misspecification. Overvaluation episodes—most notably the late 1990s—mean-revert as market discipline reasserts itself.

Bottom line: the model “fails” when markets panic — and reliably re-anchors valuation once sentiment normalizes.

 

*   *   *

 

So, what does this actually mean for Home Depot?

Insight #1: capital discipline is the valuation anchor

Home Depot’s high valuation multiple is not fragile.  It is anchored in:

  • Consistent leverage
  • Predictable scaling of equity
  • Transparent capital return policy

Any unexpected shift in capital structure — aggressive deleveraging or sudden debt expansion — would matter far more to valuation than a bad margin quarter.

Insight #2: profitability matters — but only if it is repeatable

Operational improvements (margin, turnover, ROA) explain about one quarter of valuation variation.  That is meaningful — but markets discount one-off wins.  Investors prefer:

  • Incremental improvements
  • Predictable execution
  • Fewer surprises

Spectacular quarters impress analysts. Consistent ones move valuation.

Insight #3: macro matters less than headlines suggest

Despite constant focus on rates, housing cycles, and sentiment, macro variables explain only a single-digit share of long-term valuation variation.  Home Depot’s valuation history is fundamentally a company-driven story, not a macro-driven one.

Once full-year 2025 financials are available, we will:

  • Re-estimate the model
  • Test coefficient stability
  • Re-evaluate valuation implications under the new regime and compare/contrast the hedonic pricing model with the traditional DCF valuation model

If history is any guide, the conclusion is unlikely to change — but the path may.

 

Final thought

Markets are often accused of being short-term and irrational. Over 35 years of Home Depot data suggests the opposite.

Investors are remarkably consistent in what they reward.

They pay for persistency.

entry.title: Stock transport order API has no ability to change ship to address
entry.content:
The Stock transport order API has no ability to change ship to address.  We have a business need to transfer materials from one plant to another plant (representing an Amazon Distribution Center).  The addresses of the specific Amazon Distribution Centers are dynamic in nature.  We would like the ability to update the ship to address (seems to be defaulted to the receiving plant address) when creating the STO via the API.  Please advise.  This functionality is available via the UI.  


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

This API from the business accelerator has no fields for address input. 




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Stock transport order API has no ability to change sh...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the Stock Transport Order (STO) API – CE_STOCKTRANSPORTORDER_0001 is working as designed.

Why the Ship-To Address Cannot Be Changed via API

  • In S/4HANA Cloud, an STO is a plant-to-plant logistics document.

  • The Ship-To address is always derived from the receiving plant’s address (plant master data).

  • The public API does not expose address fields for STO creation because:

    • Allowing free-form or dynamic addresses would break core logistics and inventory valuation logic

    • STOs are tightly coupled with plant determination, stock postings, and follow-on documents

  • Therefore, changing the Ship-To address via API is intentionally restricted.

 This is standard product behavior, not a technical gap or API defect.

 

Why It Works in the UI but Not in the API

  •  the system may allow temporary/manual address adjustments (for example, for output or delivery purposes).

  • However:

    • These changes do not change the underlying plant determination

    • The API strictly follows the business object contract and does not support such overrides

The Stock Transport Order API does not support changing the Ship-To address because, in S/4HANA Cloud, STOs are strictly plant-to-plant documents. The Ship-To address is always derived from the receiving plant master data. While the UI may allow limited manual adjustments, this is not exposed in the public API by design.

For dynamic Amazon Distribution Center addresses, SAP recommends modeling each DC as a separate plant or using a different business process (such as customer or intercompany scenarios) that supports dynamic addresses via API.

 

Thank you

entry.title: Re: Can the cost center cost allocation cycle rule select...
entry.content:
Hello @frezhang 

Thank you for your question

 

To answer your question on “if this is a missing configuration”. The answer is no. You not finding the Actual Activity is because it is not offered as a variable portion type. The reason is described in KBA 3338660.

However, for Actual allocation, the system provides some Variable Portion Types that are typically limited to items like:

  • Actual amounts. This covers your transactional, local and group currency
  • Actual Quantities
  • Statistical Key Figures

So, you will only see those mentioned and not Actual Activity. KBA 3407708 describes how you can use it.

In public cloud you can workaround this depending on what you require:

1. If your driver is an activity quantity, then you should use SKF-Actual. You can do this by:

  • Creating an SKF that represents the activity driver (which could be machine hours, labour hours, etc.) and post actual SKF quantities.
  • As a Variable Portion Type in the allocation cycle ensure you use SKF- Actual

2. If you truly need activity type-based allocation, then use Activity Allocation apps or process, not universal Allocation variable portions to achieve that goal. Activity type logic is handled in the activity allocation framework and not as a tracing factor in Manage Allocation.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

To summarise, the public cloud does not allow you to add an ECC style ALV Subtotal or Total” button to just any custom or standard list. Basically saying, ther is no classis ALV toolbar enhancement in the User Interface.

entry.title: Re: Check data and specify void reason code INTERCOMPANY...
entry.content:
Good day @AreebaZakir 

Thank you for your question

From your screenshot I can see you are in GUI and not a public cloud Fiori flow.

That said, the message you have on your screen means the system will only allow you to cancel or reverse your task if you enter the mandatory void reason code. In other words, you have to specify a legal or compliance reason for cancelling the document. Once you have completed this, the system will unblock the reversal.

If you are using the public cloud, ensure:

  • You use Reverse Journal Entries or Manage Journal Entries app, find the entry you wish to reverse.

  • Then maintain your reversal reason in the appointed dialog. If the system prompts for Void Reason Code, open the value help and select the correct reason.

  • Should your tenant not have void reason code list, then you do not have the necessary configuration for the reason code. You can maintain this in public cloud through the Central Business Configuration.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Delete Completed item of service order
entry.content:
Good day @Lily16 

Thank you for your question

Based on your screenshot, your item 30 is completed and you normally cannot delete it in the sense of removing it from the PO. In the public cloud, once GR, invoice exit, the system keeps the audit trail. However, what you can do is reverse the GR and invoice first and then set the item to Deleted or close it correctly.

The summary on how to proceed is to:

  • Post a return for the GR if you received goods, and
  • Post a credit memo for the invoice, then
  • Leave your PO item as completed for traceability.

Please note that this process does not erase history. Rather it blocks further processing and removes it from your operational flow lists.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

Hello @thongle3103

No, it is not because it is not released for cloud development. The Free Form Payment app works on the concept of payment requests.

I am not aware of any released CDS view for payment request. See: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/031c345485b84c8c94265be9ef61d3a8/67a84bce46254a6c840a9eb873a158e4.html?locale=en-US for more details.

I suggest you read the payment request data through released APIs rather than direct CDS access. You can search for payment Request in the Business Accelerator Hub, filter for public cloud Edition, then use the released API to extract the payment request data and persist it to your extension. You may also consume it directly in your integration.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Legacy Data Transfer - Security Positions
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily outlines the process of transferring legacy data of security positions (bond, stock, investment certificate, etc.) from external systems into the Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) module, as a critical step in initial go-live data migration. The process is illustrated using an example of bond issuance in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is recommended:

  • The position components constitute the financial position of an interest rate instrument – refer to blog Position Changes and Postings Across the Life of an Interest Rate Instrument or relevant SAP held documents for detailed context.
  • How accrual of interest income or expenses works – refer to blog Accrual: Reset Procedure and Difference Procedure or relevant SAP held documents for detailed context.

The above-referenced blogs use OTC money market instrument for illustration, but the underlying principles are similar in essence.

It is also recommended reading the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which may help you gain insights into the differences between OTC transactions’ legacy data transfer and security positions’ legacy data transfer.

Migration of Transactions (?)

A frequently asked question is whether security transactions need to be imported into SAP TRM and how to handle them?

Actually, there is no need to import security transactions. Unlike OTC transactions— which serve as the core "carrier" (referred to as a differentiation term in SAP TRM terminology) for position management purpose and must be imported into the system—security positions are the result of the combined effect of multiple purchase/placement transactions, sale/redemption transactions, valuations, and other business transactions. Therefore, for data migration, it is sufficient to import the position of a specific security class in a given security account (disregarding discussion of other differentiation terms here) as of the cut-off date. Furthermore, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit does not provide a migration object for importing security transactions.

Creation of Master Data

Before importing the position data for security, two master data should be created: security class, security account.

Security Class

The specific steps for creating a security class are not elaborated on here. We assume the following security class has been created in SAP TRM.

Key elements of this security class:

  • Issue start: 01.10.2025
  • Issue end: 01.04.2026
  • Issuance currency: USD
  • Coupon rate: 3% (act/360)
  • Coupon frequency: every 2 months
  • Redemption structure: financial repayment

Simulate Cash flow (for position category “Liability”):

Security Account

The process of creating a security account (for issuance purpose) is omitted herein.

Enter Data of Position Indicator

Since the position indicator for security position can’t be generated through creation of security transaction (as aforementioned, security transaction creation is not required), you can use the app Enter Data of Security Position Indicators (app ID: TPM61A) to maintain the position indicator data for the security position.

In this example, we will always focus on valuation area 003 only, the details for legacy data transfer of other valuation areas are omitted although they are also needed.

Transfer Data of Security Position Indicators

With the app Transfer Data of Security Position Indicators (app ID: TPM61), you create the position indicator for the security class within the security account, and the subledger position indicator (for valuation area 003) is also created, based on the data maintained in TPM61A.

Log after successful execution of TPM61A:

Open app Manage Position Indicator (app ID: TPM57A) to check in the position indicator:

After the creation of position indicator, the security position value data should be then migrated, there are two parts for position value data of security:

  • Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions
  • Valuation Area-dependent Data of Security Positions

In this example, let’s assume that the go-live of TRM is planned at 01.01.2026, so the position values of this security class within the issuance security account as of 31.12.2025 should be migrated from position management and financial accounting perspectives.

Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions

With app Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions (app ID: TPM63A), you enter the valuation area-independent data of security positions for the position value date. You specify, for example, the nominal amount, purchase values, and capitalized costs in addition to the quantity information (units or nominal amounts).

This following table contains the data to be entered in TPM63A for this example:

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

Position Value Date

31.12.2025

 

Company Code

1010

 

General Valuation Class

26

 

Security Class

BND_TEST_01

 

Securities Account

ISSUANCE

 

Position Currency

USD

 

Local Currency

EUR

In this example, the local currency of company code 1010 is EUR

Assets/Liabs Pos.

Liability Posit

Enter “Liability Posit” in the example since it is bond issuance.

Calculation Date

31.12.2025

 

Units

Blank

Used for unit-quoted security

Original Nominal Amount PC

Blank

Used for bonds with installment repayments (ABS/MBS)

Nominal Amount

100,000,000.00

Used for percentage-quoted security. Always enter positive value.

In this example, the nominal of the issued bond is 100M USD.

Nominal Currency

USD

 

Purchase Value in PC

-98,000,000.00

Enter positive value for asset position, enter negative value for liability position.

In this example, the bond is issued at 98% of its face value, so the purchase value is 98,000,000.00, with the discount amounting to 2,000,000.00 USD.

Purchase Value in LC

-83,456,800.00

In this example, the exchange rate USD/EUR as of the issuing date (01.10.2025) = 0.8516, 98,000,000.00*0.8516=83,456,800.00 EUR.

Costs in Pos.Crcy

12,000.00

In this example, the issuance cost for bond is12,000.00 USD.

Cost in LC

10,219.20

12,000.00**0.8516=10,219.20 EUR.

Screen-shots of TPM63A:

Notes:

  • Not every available field of TPM63A are listed in the above table.
  • You may always find more comprehensive information from help document Enter Valuation Area-Independent Data of Security Positions.
  • For legacy data transfer of OTC transactions, the position component purchase value can’t be specified in TPM63C, because it has been determined by the operational cash flow within the OTC transaction. However, for legacy data transfer of security positions, it is needed to specify the purchase value in TPM63A, because security transactions are not migrated.
  • In this example, the unamortized discount as of issuing date = 2,000.000.00 + 12,000.00 = 2,012,000.00 USD.

Enter Valuation Area-Dependent Data of Security Positions

Now, let’s enter the valuation area-dependent position component values for this security position by using the app Enter Valuation Area-Dependent Data of Security Positions (app ID: TPM63B). Screen-shots:

Elaborate the data entered in TPM63B in below table:

Field

Data used in this example

Remark for the field

Position Value Date

31.12.2025

 

Company Code

1010

 

General Valuation Class

26

 

Valuation Area

003

 

Security Class

BND_TEST_01

 

Securities Account

ISSUANCE

 

Position Currency

USD

 

Valuation Currency

EUR

In this example, the valuation currency is EUR (=local currency of company code 1010 )

Assets/Liabs Pos.

Liability Posit

Enter “Liability Posit” in the example since it is bond issuance.

Security Valuation in Position Currency

Blank

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, no security valuation should be migrated since issued bond is evaluated at historical cost (amortized cost).

Security Valuation in Valuation Currency

Blank

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

FX Valuation in Valuation Currency

180,000.00

Positive value for write-up; Negative value for write-down.

In this example, this amount is the FX valuation recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Amortization in Position Currency

- 997,017.02

Positive value for positive amortization; Negative value for negative amortization.

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in PC (part of the initial discount 2,012,000.00 USD) which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Amortization in Valuation Currency

-849,059.69

In this example, this amount is the amortization amount in VC which has been recognized up to 31.12.2025 for the issued bond in the legacy system.

Discount in PC

-1.014.982,98

Positive value for premium, negative value for discount, in case of liability position; Positive value for discount, negative value for premium, in case of asset position.

This is only needed when the amortization procedure of the position management procedure uses ‘gross method’ in SAP TRM; if amortization procedure uses ‘net method’, then there’s no need to enter value for these two fields of ‘Discount’ within TPM63B.

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in PC as of 31.12.2025.

Discount in VC

-864.359,51

In this example, this amount is the remaining unamortized discount in VC as of 31.12.2025.

Accrual/deferral (1) in position currency

-258,333.33

Usually, enter positive value for accrual of income from investment, or deferral of expenses from issuance; enter negative value for accrual of expenses from issuance, or deferral of income from investment.

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in PC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system, and the assumption is that SAP TRM use reset procedure for TPM44 accrual after go-live.

Accrual/deferral (1) in valuation currency

-219,531.66

In this example, this amount is the balance of accrual account (liability) in VC as of 31.12.2025 in the legacy system.

Accrual/deferral with Reset

X

If this indicator is set, a reset business transaction for the transferred accruals/deferrals is generated additionally.

Reset Date

01.01.2026

If the reset date is not entered, the reset will occur on “position value date + 1”.

Notes: Not every available field of TPM63B are listed in the above table.

Initial Load of Position Values

After the data has been entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, use the app Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM63) to read legacy data you’ve entered in TPM63A and TPM63B, and transfer it to the position management of TRM for this security position.

There are 3 options for “Accounting Update”:

  • Do Not Update: choose this option if the accounting data is migrated via other means other than TRM (e.g. migrated the balances of position account, discount account, accrual account in general ledger accounting). No posting will be generated from TPM63 if this option is selected.
  • Update: choose this option and then TPM63 will generate accounting documents for legacy data transfer related business transactions, usually using update type DT_*; and the postings rely on the account determination setup for those update types.
  • Update Only for Reset Business Transactions: if you have migrated accounting data by other means only up to the transfer key date, and you would like to post the reset business transactions (for amortizations, valuations, or accruals/deferrals) through TPM63, you can choose this option.

In this example, we choose Update to illustrate the whole picture of postings.

Log for TPM63 run:

You can also check the posting log by clicking Logs and Messages, the screen-shot is omitted here. Instead, let’s use the T-accounts to illustrate the effects of postings generated from TPM63 run:

The bond payable, unamortized discount, and accrual account, all of the relevant balance sheet accounts have correctly reflected the balances which are equal to the legacy system’s data for this security position, in both of position currency and valuation currency. The Financial Statement of Position as of reporting date 31.12.2025 then can be properly prepared in SAP system.

In this example, the “gross method” is used for the amortization procedure. Therefore, the bond payable account reflects the face value of the issued bonds (100,000,000.00 USD / 84,980,000.00 EUR). From an accounting standpoint, the carrying amount of the security position is calculated as the face value minus the unamortized discount (1,014,982.98 USD / 864,359.51 EUR), resulting in 98,985,017.02 USD / 84,115,640.49 EUR.

You may wonder why accrual is reset on 01.01.2026—this is to ensure the accuracy of interest expenses for the month of January 2026 under the reset procedure of TPM44. For a detailed explanation of the rationale, please refer to the blog Legacy Data Transfer - OTC Transactions, which elaborates on the underlying reasons. While this blog uses an example of an investment OTC transaction, the core logic is consistent with the security position scenario, so we will not repeat the details here. This same blog also covers the handling of legacy data transfer for the difference procedure of TPM44, which requires assigning additional update types in configuration activity 104457 “Assign Additional Update Types for Difference Procedure”, we will not elaborate further on this configuration step and process of difference procedure either.

Check the position flows in TPM13:

Check the position component values in TPM12 as of 31.12.2025:

Illustrate the calculation logic of position component values in the following manner:

Additional Notes

  • You may always find more comprehensive information from help document Legacy Data Transfer.
  • Which DT_* update types are invoked for TPM63 is specified in configuration activity 106944 “Assign Update Types for Legacy Data Transfer”. Sample configuration:

  • This blog only outlines certain means and posting patterns associated with legacy data transfer; such postings can vary based on specific business requirements and can be implemented with the various flexibilities offered by the SAP system.
  • App Reverse Transfer of Security Position Indicator (app ID: TPM62) is used to reverse the transfer done by TPM61.
  • App Reverse Initial Load of Position Values - Legacy Data Transfer (app ID: TPM64) is used to reverse results from TPM63.

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Hiding dimensions used for filtering from...
entry.content:
Hi Dimitar, 

in BW you mean that you can create a sub-query as filter, or you mean when creating the query, you can use global filter which is not visible for the user, but the characteristics / info-object has to be in the Multi, or Cube, or aDSO or openODS (could also be a field-based). But you could not hide the Info-object in the provider self. 

I do understand your point. I run into the very same issue, with BW however as well. Always to explain the difference of an NAV/DIS attribute and transactional data. Well very same in DSP, just that in DSP there is no Query object. You have only the provider level (BW-like). So no, you cannot filter and hide a dimension. You can use a filter in a Story (script it or create it, but only in Story not when you include the model/exposed view).

Suggestion. Materialize the MAT_SALES__0VENDOR in the Model-View (FACT level) and create a parameter, wich you consume via the AM. In the AM you would not provide MAT_SALES__0VENDOR, but still can filter on it via the parameter.

Martin

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Hiding dimensions used for filtering from...
entry.content: Hi Martin. The point I was trying to make in BW, is that you can define a filter on MAT_SALES_0VENDOR without having it in the query structure nor as a free characteristic. Input Parameter is not an option since this Fact View is used for different reports where not every one of them uses the same prompt and consequently has a filter on  MAT_SALES__0VENDOR

entry.title: Re: Datasphere: Hiding dimensions used for filtering from...
entry.content: I see. In BW you still have to have the info object in the provider. In DSP you do not have a Query object, only Provider. Then you will need to copy the model-view, create a parameter and use it in AM. Or if your MAT_SALES__0VENDOR (NAV attr) is static, create kind of lookup-table and have it filtered in the view without parameter and create AMs as Query-Views. Martin

entry.title: Data Lakes Files physical storage and Object Store in Datasphere & BDC context
entry.content:
Greetings SAP experts!

For some time I am trying to understand some concepts in regards to the Object Store and Data Lake Files physical storage in Datasphere & BDC context.

First I will start with naming the main service components of the SAP HANA Cloud that you can subscribe in SAP BTP:

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database
  • SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake further formed from:
    • Data Lake Files
    • Data Lake Relational Engine

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud/sap-hana-cloud-getting-started-guide/sap-hana-cloud-components

Now let's start with SAP Datasphere

When we have a Customer Managed Space:

  • With Storage Type SAP HANA Database (Disk and In-Memory) -> I believe physical storage will be in SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database on which the Datasphere tenant itself relies on.
  • When it comes to Storage Type SAP HANA Data Lake Files:
    • Where are the Data Lake Files behind the Local Table(file) physically stored?
      • In the Object Store?
        • If yes - What kind of Object Store is used?
          • SAP Managed Object Store (File Container)?
          • External Object Store (Azure Blob Storage / Azure Data Lake, AWS S3 bucket, Google Cloud Storage bucket)
      • In the SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Files (service component) of the SAP HAHA Cloud underlying SAP Datasphere tenant?

Further, in BDC context.

  • Let's say we activated a Data Package from BDC Cockpit, APRS starts pushing data to target HANA Data Lake Files i.e. SAP BDC Foundational services (FOS) layer.
    • Again, where are these Data Lake Files physically stored?

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud-data-lake/welcome-guide/sap-hana-cloud-data-lake-terminology

https://help.sap.com/docs/object-store/object-store-service-on-sap-btp/what-is-object-store

 

Really appreciate any input helping me to clarify these topics.

Kind regards!
